revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=March 2015}} {{Year nav topic5|1580|architecture}} {| class="infobox" |- style="background-color:#f3f3f3" | align="center" | [[1570s in architecture|1570s]] <sup>.</sup> '''1580s in architecture''' <sup>.</sup> [[1590s in architecture|1590s]] |- | align="center" | <small>other events: 1580s</small> <sup>.</sup> [[Architecture timeline]] |} __TOC__
==Buildings== * 1580 – [[Old City of Zamość]], designed by [[Bernardo Morando]], is established in [[Poland]]. * 1580–1588 – [[Wollaton Hall]] near [[Nottingham]] in England, probably designed by [[Robert Smythson]], is built. * 1581 ** [[Uffizi]] in [[Florence]], designed by [[Giorgio Vasari]] and continued by [[Alfonso Parigi the Elder]] and [[Bernardo Buontalenti]], is completed. ** [[Litomyšl]] Castle in Bohemia, begun in 1568, is completed. * c. 1582 – Dome and lantern of the church of [[Santa Maria di Loreto, Rome]], completed by [[Giacomo del Duca]]. * 1583 ** [[Allahabad Fort]], built by [[Emperor Akbar]], is completed. ** [[Quirinal Palace]] in Rome, designed by [[Carlo Maderno]] and [[Domenico Fontana]], is begun. ** New [[Basilica of Our Lady of Humility]], [[Pistoia]], [[Tuscany]], is consecrated.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Lady of Humility Basilica|url=http://www.basilicadellamadonna.it/basilica_eng.html|publisher=Santuario Basilica Madonna dell'Umiltà|location=Pistoia|year=2005|accessdate=2015-03-18|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923182520/http://www.basilicadellamadonna.it/basilica_eng.html|archive-date=2015-09-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> * 1584 ** [[El Escorial]] palace at [[San Lorenzo de El Escorial]], Spain (begun [[1563 in architecture|1563]]), designed by [[Juan de Herrera]], is completed. ** [[Church of the Gesù]] in Rome, designed by [[Giacomo Barozzi da Vignola]] in [[1560s in architecture|1568]] and completed by [[Giacomo della Porta]] with "the first truly [[Baroque architecture|baroque]] façade", is consecrated.<ref>{{cite journal|first=Nathan T.|last=Whitman|title=Roman Tradition and the Aedicular Façade|journal=[[Journal of the Society of Architectural Historians]]|volume=29|issue=2|year=1970|pages=108–123|doi=10.2307/988645}}</ref> [[File:Vista aerea del Monasterio de El Escorial.jpg|thumb|350px|[[El Escorial]]]] * 1585 – [[Teatro Olimpico]], [[Vicenza]], designed by [[Palladio]], and completed by [[Vincenzo Scamozzi]], is opened. * 1585 – [[Neubau (Strasbourg)|Neubau]] in [[Strasbourg]], begun in 1582, is inaugurated. * 1586 – [[Golden Tea Room]] first recorded in use in Japan. * 1587–1588 – [[Fort Al Jalali]] at [[Muscat, Oman]], is built by Portuguese naval captain [[Belchior Calaça]]. * 1588 ** [[Teatro all'antica|Court theatre]] at [[Sabbioneta]], designed by [[Vincenzo Scamozzi]], is begun (completed [[1590s in architecture|1590]].) ** [[Ludwig Roselius Museum|Roselius-Haus]] in [[Bremen]] is completed.
==Publications== * 1584 – [[Gian Paolo Lomazzo]] produces his treatise ''Trattato dell'arte della pittura, scoltura et architettura''.
==Births== * 1585 – [[Pietro Paolo Floriani]], Italian architect and engineer (died [[1638 in architecture|1638]]) * 1587 – [[Fabio Mangone]], Italian architect (died [[1629 in architecture|1629]]) * 1587 – [[Hans van Steenwinckel the Younger]], Flemish/Danish architect (died [[1639 in architecture|1639]])
==Deaths== * 1580: August 19 – [[Andrea Palladio]], Italian architect (born [[1508 in architecture|1508]]) * 1583: October 30 – [[Pirro Ligorio]], Italian architect, painter, antiquarian and garden designer (born [[1510 in architecture|1510]]) * 1588: July 17 – [[Mimar Sinan]], Ottoman architect (born [[1489 in architecture|1489]])
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1580s architecture| ]] [[Category:1580s works|Architecture]]

{{Infobox coin | country = [[European Union]][[Institutions of the European Union|Institutions]] and the members of the [[Eurozone]] | Denomination = 1 euro | Value = 1 | Unit = [[euro]] | Mass_troy_oz = | Mass = 7.5 | Diameter_inch = | Diameter = 23.25 | Thickness_inch = | Thickness = 2.33 | Edge = Alternating segments, three smooth, three finely ribbed | Composition = Outer segment: nickel brass.
Inner segment: three layers: copper-nickel, nickel and copper-nickel. | Years of Minting = 2002–present (from 1999 only for [[France]], [[Finland]], [[Spain]], [[Belgium]] and the [[Netherlands]]; from 2001 only for [[Monaco]]) | Catalog Number = | Reverse = File:Common face of one euro coin.jpg | Reverse Design = Map of [[Europe]] with the denomination shown in [[Latin]] characters | Reverse Designer = [[Luc Luycx]] | Reverse Design Date = 2007 | Obverse = Many | Obverse Design = 26 variations, see below. | Obverse Designer = Various | Obverse Design Date = Various }} The '''1-euro coin''' ('''€1''') is a [[euro coin]] with a value of one [[euro]] (€1). It is made of two [[alloy]]s: the inner part of [[cupronickel]], the outer part of nickel [[brass]]. All coins have a common reverse side and country-specific national sides. The coin has been used since 2002, with the present common side design dating from 2007. As of July 2015, there were approximately 6.7 billion one-euro coins in circulation, constituting 26.4% of all circulated euro coins by value and 5.9% by quantity.{{cite web|url=http://www.ecb.europa.eu/stats/euro/circulation/html/index.en.html|title=Banknotes and coins circulation|accessdate=2015-09-11}} See "Circulation of euro coins, quantities report and data" and "Circulation of euro coins, values report and data" in the "Alternative data formats" section. ==History== The coin dates from 2002, when euro coins and [[euro banknotes|banknotes]] were introduced in the twelve-member [[Eurozone]] and its [[Eurozone#Use outside the Union|related territories]]. The common side was designed by [[Luc Luycx]], a [[Belgium|Belgian]] artist who won a Europe-wide competition to design the new coins. The design of the one and two euro coins was intended to show the [[European Union]] (EU) as a whole with the then 15 countries more closely joined together than on the 10- to 50-cent coins (the 1- to 5-cent coins showed the EU as one, though intending to show its place in the world). There were then 15 versions of the national sides (eurozone + [[Monaco]], [[San Marino]] and the [[Vatican City|Vatican]] who could mint their own) and in each case there was a national competition to decide the design, which had to comply with uniform specifications, such as the requirement to include twelve stars (see [[euro coins]]). National designs were not allowed to change until the end of 2008, unless a [[monarch]] (whose portrait usually appears on the coins) died or abdicated. This happened in Monaco and the Vatican City, resulting in three new designs in circulation (the Vatican had an interim ''[[sede vacante]]'' design until the new [[Pope]] was elected). National designs have seen some changes, as they are now required to include the name of the issuing country: previously neither Finland nor Belgium showed this. {{as of|2010}}, Austria, Germany and Greece are obliged to change their designs due this requirement in the future. As the [[Member state of the European Union|EU's membership]] has since [[Enlargement of the European Union|expanded]] in 2004 and 2007, with further expansions envisaged, the common face of all euro coins of values of 10 cents and above were redesigned in 2007 to show a new map. This map showed Europe, not just the EU, as one continuous landmass; however [[Cyprus]] was moved west as the map cut off after the [[Bosphorus]] (which was seen as excluding [[Turkey]] for political reasons). The 2007 redesign coincided with the first enlargement of the [[eurozone]] in that year, with the entry of [[Slovenia]]. Hence, the Slovenian design was added to the designs in circulation. Since then designs for [[Cyprus]], [[Malta]], [[Slovakia]], [[Estonia]], [[Latvia]] and [[Lithuania]] have been added as each of these states joined the eurozone. [[Andorra]] began minting its own designs in 2014 after winning the right to do so. ==Design== [[File:EUR 1 edge (2007 issue).png|thumb|Edge of all €1 coins]] The coins are composed of two alloys. The inner circle is composed of three layers ([[Cupronickel|copper-nickel]], [[nickel]], copper-nickel) and the outer ring of nickel [[brass]], giving the coin a two-colour appearance. The coin has a diameter of 23.25 mm, thickness 2.33 mm and a mass of 7.5 grams. The coins' edges consist of alternating segments: three smooth, three finely ribbed. The coins have been used from 2002, though some are dated 1999, which is the year the [[euro]] was created as a currency, but not put into general circulation. ===Reverse (common) side=== The reverse (used from 2007 onwards) was designed by Luc Luycx and displays a map of Europe, not including [[Iceland]] and cutting off, in a [[semicircle]], at the Bosphorus, north through the middle of [[Ukraine]], then [[Russia]] and through northern [[Scandinavia]]. Cyprus is located further west than it should be and Malta is shown disproportionately large so that it appears on the map. The map has numerous indentations giving an appearance of geography{{clarify|date=September 2013}} rather than a flat design. Six fine lines cut across the map except where there is landmass and have a star at each end—reflecting the twelve stars on the [[flag of Europe]]. Across the map is the word EURO, and a large number 1 appears to the left hand side of the coin. The designer's initials, LL, appear next to Cyprus. Luc Luycx designed the original coin, which was much the same except that the design was only of the then 15 members in their entirety{{clarify|date=September 2013}} and showing borders and no geographic features.{{clarify|date=September 2013}} The map was less detailed and the lines the stars were upon{{clarify|date=September 2013}} cut through where there would be landmass in [[eastern Europe]] if it were shown. ===Obverse (national) side=== The obverse side of the coin depends on the issuing country. All have to include twelve stars (in most cases a circle around the edge), the engraver's initials and the year of issue. New designs also have to include the name or initials of the issuing country. The side cannot repeat the denomination of the coin unless the issuing country uses an alphabet other than [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] (currently, [[Greece]] is the only such country, hence "1 ΕΥΡΩ" is engraved upon its coin. [[Austria]] is currently in breach of the revised rules, but has so far not announced plans to remove "1 EURO" from its coin). {| class="wikitable" !width=220px|State !Details !width=100px|Years |- !{{flagicon|Andorra }} [[Andorran euro coins]] |The [[Casa de la Vall]], the home of the [[General Council of Andorra]]. It features the word "Andorra" below and the year of minting. |2015 onward |- !{{flagicon|Austria}} [[Austrian euro coins]] |[[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] (with his [[signature]]), a famous German/Austrian composer, in reference to the idea of Austria as a "land of music". The Austrian flag is [[Hatching system|hatched]] below the denomination (which is against the new rules for national designs and hence will be changed at some point) on the right hand side. The year appears on the left-hand side. |2002 onward |- !rowspan=3|{{flagicon|Belgium}} [[Belgian euro coins]] |FIRST SERIES: An [[effigy]] of [[Albert II of Belgium|King Albert II]]. To the right-hand side among the stars was the kings [[monogram]], a letter "A", underneath a crown. The year is lower down, also among the stars. |2002–2007 |- |SECOND SERIES: A redesign to include the letters BE (standing for Belgium) beneath the monogram, which was moved out of the stars into the centre circle but still to the right of the King's renewed portrait. The date was also moved out and placed beneath the effigy and included two symbols either side (left: signature mark of the master of the mint, right: mint mark). |2008–2013 |- |THIRD SERIES: In 2013, Albert II abdicated with [[Philippe of Belgium]] becoming King. He subsequently replaced Albert on Belgian coins. |2014 onward |- !{{flagicon|Cyprus}} [[Cypriot euro coins]] |[[Idol of Pomos]], a [[prehistory|prehistoric]] [[sculpture]] dating from the 30th century BC, is an example of the island's historic civilisation and art. It includes the name of Cyprus in [[Greek language|Greek]] and [[Turkish language|Turkish]] (ΚΥΠΡΟΣ and KIBRIS) each side of the idol. |2008 onward |- !{{flagicon|Estonia}} [[Estonian euro coins]] |A geographical image of Estonia and the word "Eesti" ("Estonia"). |2011 onward |- !rowspan=2|{{flagicon|Finland}} [[Finnish euro coins]] |FIRST SERIES: Two [[whooper swan]]s (the national bird of Finland) flying over Finnish landscape, the date is visible in the landscape to the lower right. The coin was designed by [[Pertti Mäkinen]] and commemorates the 80th anniversary of the [[independence of Finland]]. The first series included the initial of the mint master of the Mint of Finland, Raimo Makkonen (an M), to the left side of the horizon. |2002–2007 |- |SECOND SERIES: Redesign to meet the new design requirements, the initial was replaced by the mint's mint mark and the letters FI (for Finland) were included on the right-hand side of the horizon. Changes in the mint mark occurred several times since 2007. |2007 onward |- !{{flagicon|France}} [[French euro coins]] |A stylised tree (which symbolises life, continuity and growth) upon a [[hexagon]] (''l'hexagone'' is often used to refer to France due to its broadly hexagonal shape). The letters RF, standing for République française (French Republic), stand each side of the trunk of the tree. Around the edge, but inside the circle of stars, is the motto of France: “[[liberté, égalité, fraternité]]”. The stars themselves are stylised, linked together by a pattern of lines. The date is located towards the bottom between the stars and the mint marks are located at the top. |2002 onward |- !{{flagicon|Germany}} [[German euro coins]] |The [[Coat of arms of Germany|German coat of arms]] (the German eagle) which symbolises German sovereignty. The date appears at the base of the eagle and the gold behind the stars is etched to give visual effect. |2002 onward |- !{{flagicon|Greece}} [[Greek euro coins]] |Based on a 5th-century BC four-[[Greek drachma|drachma]] coin from [[Athens]]. The coin is of an owl (a symbol of Athens) with an olive branch to the top left. The outline of the old coin is still shown and the value of the euro in the Greek alphabet, 1 ΕΥΡΩ, is shown on the right-hand side. The mint's mark is to the top and the date on the bottom side among the stars. |2002 onward |- !{{flagicon|Ireland}} [[Irish euro coins]] |The national emblem of Ireland, an Irish harp (the Cláirseach, see [[Clàrsach]]). Vertically on the left-hand side is the word "[[Éire]]" (Ireland in the [[Irish language]]) and on the right-hand side is the date. The harp motif was designed by Jarlath Hayes. |2002 onward |- !{{flagicon|Italy}} [[Italian euro coins]] |The 15th-century "[[Vitruvian Man]]" drawing by [[Leonardo da Vinci]] which depicted the ideal proportions of a human body. Leonardo's work is highly symbolic as it represents the [[Renaissance]] focus on man as the measure of all things, and has simultaneously a round shape that fits the coin perfectly. As [[Carlo Azeglio Ciampi]] observed, this represents the "coin to the service of Man", instead of Man to the service of money. It includes the interconnected letters IR (for ''Repubblica Italiana'' – Italian Republic). The year is to the right of the human body and the mint mark to the left. |2002 onward |- !{{flagicon|Latvia}} [[Latvian euro coins]] |The [[5 lats coin|Latvian maiden]] with "Latvijas Republika" written either side. |2014 onward |- !{{flagicon|Lithuania}} [[Lithuanian euro coins]] |[[Coat of arms of Lithuania|Vytis]] (symbol of the coat of arms) and the word "Lietuva", which means "Lithuania". The twelve stars, symbols of the EU, surrounds the Vytis. |2015 onward |- !{{flagicon|Luxembourg}} [[Luxembourgish euro coins]] |A stylised effigy of [[Henri, Grand Duke of Luxembourg|Grand Duke Henri of Luxembourg]]. The left 40% of the coin has the effigy cut off and the style of the stars inverted. The year, followed by ''Lëtzebuerg'' (Luxembourg in [[Luxembourgish language|Luxembourgish]]) written vertically. |2002 onward |- !{{flagicon|Malta}} [[Maltese euro coins]] |The [[Maltese Cross]] (the emblem of the [[Sovereign Military Order of Malta]]: 1520–1798, now a national symbol), with the background of a darker hatched texture. The word MALTA is shown with each letter appearing in a segment across the top half of the coin to the edge of the inner circle. The date is shown at the base of the inner circle. |2008 onward |- !rowspan=2|{{flagicon|Monaco}} [[Monégasque euro coins]] |FIRST SERIES: Effigies of both [[Rainier III, Prince of Monaco|Prince Rainier III]] (monarch) and [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco|Prince Albert II]] (next in line). The name MONACO was written across the top of the coin and the year across the bottom with the mint marks. |2002–2006 |- |SECOND SERIES: Upon the death of Prince Rainier III in 2005, and the accession of Prince Albert II, the coin design was changed to just show the effigy of Prince Albert II. The rest of the design stayed the same except for the name Monaco and the date moving within the inner circle. |2006 onward |- !rowspan=2|{{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Dutch euro coins]] |FIRST SERIES: A stylised profile of Queen [[Beatrix of the Netherlands]] over the left half of the coin, with the right hand side containing the words "Beatrix Koningin der Nederlanden" ("Beatrix Queen of The Netherlands" in Dutch) written vertically on three lines and the year written horizontally to the lower right. This design was taken from the former [[Dutch guilder]]. The mint marks are located on the bottom of the outer ring and the twelve stars are compressed onto the left side of the coin only, rather than forming a full circle. |2002–2013 |- |SECOND SERIES: In 2013 [[Willem-Alexander of the Netherlands]] acceded to the Dutch throne. New coins with his effigy are being minted from 2014 which maintain a similar design. |2014 onward |- !{{flagicon|Portugal}} [[Portuguese euro coins]] |The royal seal of 1144 surrounded by the country's castles and five [[Escutcheon (heraldry)|escutcheona]] with silver [[bezant]]s set in relation to the surrounding European stars which is supposed to symbolise dialogue, exchange of values and dynamics in the building of Europe. Between the castles is the numbers of the year towards the bottom and the letters of the name Portugal between the upper icons. The stars are inset on a ridge. |2002 onward |- !rowspan=2|{{flagicon|San Marino}} [[Sammarinese euro coins]] |FIRST SERIES: The [[coat of arms of San Marino]]. The date is located to the top left and the mint mark to the top right. San Marino is written along the bottom of the coat of arms. |2002-2017 |- |SECOND SERIES: The [[Three Towers of San Marino|Second Tower]]. |2018 onward |- !{{flagicon|Slovakia}} [[Slovak euro coins]] |The [[Coat of arms of Slovakia]], a double cross on three hills extending across the lower three stars. The background is a relief of rocks, representing the stability and strength of Slovakia. "SLOVENSKO" (Slovakia) is written to the right of the emblem and the date to the lower left. The designer's initials appear under the right branch of the cross, and the mint mark under the left branch. |2009 onward |- !{{flagicon|Slovenia}} [[Slovenian euro coins]] |The coin contains a portrait of [[Primož Trubar]], a Protestant reformer and author of the first book written in the [[Slovene language]]. Around the portrait are the words "Stati inu obstati" (to stand and withstand) and the letters of the name SLOVENIJA (Slovenia) are placed between the stars on the right-hand side. On the left-hand side the date is located between the stars and the mint mark is next to the bottom star; however, it has changed several times since 2007. |2007 onward |- !rowspan=3|{{flagicon|Spain}} [[Spanish euro coins]] |FIRST SERIES: An effigy of [[Juan Carlos I of Spain|King Juan Carlos I]] designed by Luis José Díaz. To his left on a curved raised area is the name "España" (Spain) and four stars on the right-hand size are on a raise area in the same manner. The mint mark is located beneath España and the date on the lower portion between the stars. |2002–2009 |- |SECOND SERIES: The second design removed the curved raised area for the country's name and the stars, and moving the date from the outer ring of the coin. |2010–2015 |- |THIRD SERIES: In 2014, [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]] abdicated in favour of his son. In June 2014 the coronation took place and 8 months later (February 2015) the new design was released. |2015 onward |- !rowspan=5|{{flagicon|Vatican}} [[Vatican euro coins]] |FIRST SERIES: An effigy of [[Pope John Paul II]]. The name ''CITTA DEL VATICANO'' ([[Vatican City]]), followed by the year and mint mark, was written in a break between the stars below. |2002–2005 |- |SECOND SERIES: Following the death of John Paul II in 2005, a new coin was issued during the [[Sede vacante]] until a new Pope was chosen. This contained the insignia of the [[Apostolic Camera|Apostolic Chamber]] and the coat of arms of the [[Camerlengo of the Holy Roman Church|Cardinal Chamberlain]]. |2005–2006 |- |THIRD SERIES: When [[Pope Benedict XVI]] was elected, his effigy appeared on the coins, with the name of the city now broken to his top right with the year and mint mark in the middle to his right. |2006–2013 |- |FOURTH SERIES: In 2014 the coins were updated with the election of [[Pope Francis]]. ''CITTA DEL VATICANO'' is written around the top, broken by Pope Francis's head, with the date below the O in Vaticano. |2014–2016 |- |FIFTH SERIES: After the announcement that Pope Francis would not appear on any coins issued by the Vatican, a new 1-euro coin was issued depicting the papal coat of arms of Francis. |2017 onward |} ====Planned designs==== {{See also|Enlargement of the eurozone}} Austria, Germany and Greece will at some point need to update their designs to comply with guidelines stating they must include the issuing state's name or initial, and not repeat the denomination of the coin. In addition, there are several EU states that have not yet adopted the euro, some of them have already agreed upon their coin designs; however, it is not know exactly when they will adopt the currency, and hence these are not yet minted. See [[enlargement of the Eurozone]] for expected entry dates of these countries. ====Minting==== One-euro coins have been produced every year in Belgium, Finland, France, the Netherlands and Spain. In Austria, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Luxemburg, Portugal, San Marino and the Vatican City no €1 coins were minted dated 1999, 2000 and 2001. In [[Monaco]], no €1 coins were minted in 1999, 2000, 2005, 2008 and 2010. Malta did not issue €1 coins in 2009. Slovenia and Slovakia have produced coins every year since their respective entries to the eurozone. [[Proof coinage|Proof]] €1 coins are minted by the majority, but not all, of the eurozone states. One of the most valuable planned issues of a €1 coin was by Vatican City in 2002, which may sell for several hundred euros.{{cite web | url=http://www.coinweek.com/world-coins/the-coin-analyst-collecting-vatican-coins-can-be-rewarding-in-many-ways/ | title=Collecting Vatican Coins Can Be Rewarding in Many Ways | date = 12 November 2014 | website = coinweek.com | accessdate = 24 November 2014}} However, the French mint marks were mistakenly not placed on some 2007 Monaco coins which are hence worth more than €200 to collectors.{{citation needed|date=January 2011}} {|class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" ! rowspan="2" | Country !! rowspan="2" | Issues

|- |colspan="36" style="text-align: left; padding: 0;"| {| width="100%" |style="width: 25%; border: 0;"| {{legend|#90ff90|green – €1 coin minted}} |style="width: 25%; border: 0;"| {{legend|#ff9090|red – €1 coin was not minted}} |style="width: 25%; border: 0;"| {{legend|#ececec|grey – not yet part of the eurozone}} |} |} PP means the proof-condition coins. Numbers means if more than one coin was minted in that year in that condition by the country. In Germany, there are five [[Identifying marks on euro coins|mint marks]], so they mint ten types of coins in every year. In Greece, there were coins in 2002 which were minted in Finland with S mint mark. In the Vatican, there were coins minted with [[John Paul II]]'s effigy, and with "Sede Vacante" image in 2005. ==Error coins== There are several error 1-euro coins: Italian types from 2002 without mintmarks; Portuguese coins, also from 2002 with another type of edging (29 stripes instead of 28) and from 2008 with the first type of the common side, officially used until 2007; and the famous Monegasque coin from 2007 without mint marks. ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Euro coins (1 euro)}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.ecb.europa.eu/euro/coins/1euro/html/index.en.html|title=National sides: €1|publisher=European Central Bank|accessdate=18 August 2009}} * [http://www.euro-auflagen.de/ Information about the euro coin issues] {{Euro topics |state=expanded}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1 Euro Coins}} [[Category:Euro coins]] [[Category:Bi-metallic coins]] [[Category:One-base-unit coins]] [[Category:Maps in art]]

{{Orphan|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox company | name = 3D Repo Ltd | logo = 3D Repo Logo.svg | caption= Logo of 3D Repo Ltd | type = Privately held company | industry = Software | founded = April 28, 2014 | hq_location_country = London, United Kingdom | key_people = John Davis
(Chairman)
Dr Jozef Doboš
(CEO) | website = http://3drepo.org }} '''3D Repo Ltd''' is a [[Software as a service|Software as a Service (SaaS)]] platform provider of [[Building information modeling|Building Information Modeling (BIM)]] solutions. The company was founded in 2014 by Jozef Doboš as a spin-off from his [[Engineering Doctorate]] in Virtual Environments, Imaging and Visualisation at [[University College London]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.growthbusiness.co.uk/tech-innovators-2015-3d-repo-limited-2490931/|title=Tech Innovators 2015: 3D Repo Limited|date=2015-08-07|work=Growth Business|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-GB}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mongodb.com/blog/post/3d-repo-runs-mongodb|title=3D Repo runs in MongoDB {{!}} MongoDB Blog|work=MongoDB|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-us}} The research titled ''Management and Visualisation of Non-linear History of Polygonal 3D Models''{{Cite news|url=http://3drepo.org/projects/management-and-visualisation-of-non-linear-history-of-polygonal-3d-models/|title=Management and Visualisation of Non-linear History of Polygonal 3D Models|work=3D Repo - Collaborative online BIM platform|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}} was supervised by Prof Anthony Steed and Prof Niloy Mitra, and funded by [[Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council|EPSRC]] and Arup Foresight.{{Cite web|url=http://veiv.cs.ucl.ac.uk/people/73-people/students/290-jozef-dobos|title=Jozef Dobos|last=Pigott|first=Simon|website=veiv.cs.ucl.ac.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-10-31}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.newcivilengineer.com/future-tech/open-source-bim-platform-to-be-piloted-at-canary-wharf/8685909.article|title=Open source BIM platform to be piloted at Canary Wharf|work=New Civil Engineer|access-date=2017-11-01|language=en}} Over the years, 3D Repo won a large number of awards{{Cite web|url=http://www.constructionmanagermagazine.com/ciob-community/winners-ci7ob-innovati8on-awar2ds-unveiled/|title=Construction Manager - Home|website=www.constructionmanagermagazine.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-01}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.mongodb.com/blog/post/mongodb-innovation-award-winners|title=MongoDB Innovation Award Winners|work=MongoDB|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-us}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.cs.ucl.ac.uk/archive/article/engd_student_wins_bright_ideas_award/|title=EngD Student wins Bright Ideas Award|website=www.cs.ucl.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-11-01}} and was involved in many high-profile public as well as private construction projects including [[London Olympic Stadium]],{{Cite web|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/2034/review/london-global-university/3d-modelling-olympic-stadium|title=3D modelling for the construction industry|website=www.ucl.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-10-31}} [[Wood Wharf]],{{Cite web|url=http://aecmag.com/technology-mainmenu-35/1242-3d-repo-bim-collaboration-in-a-browser|title=3D Repo - BIM collaboration in a browser|last=Admin|website=aecmag.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-10-31}} [[Crossrail]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.i3p.org.uk/2017/01/26/crossrail-trials-digital-asset-management-3d-repo/|title=Crossrail trials Digital Asset management with 3D Repo - I3P|date=2017-01-26|work=I3P|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-GB}} and [[Smart motorway|Smart Motorways]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.constructionenquirer.com/2017/02/13/balfour-and-vinci-trial-virtual-reality-safety-training/|title=Balfour trials virtual reality safety training {{!}} Construction Enquirer|website=www.constructionenquirer.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-10-31}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.geoconnexion.com/publications/geo-uk/issue/may-june-2017-uk-issue/article/3d-repo-new-kid-on-the-block|title=3D Repo: New kid on the block {{!}} GeoConnexion|website=www.geoconnexion.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-01}} 3D Repo also provides [[Research and development|R&D]] and [[Virtual reality|VR]] capability to large construction companies such as [[Balfour Beatty]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.balfourbeatty.com/how-we-work/sustainability/sustainability-dashboard/expert/|title=Expert|website=Balfour Beatty plc|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-11-01}} and [[Skanska]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.skanska.co.uk/about-skanska/media/press-releases/202132/Skanska-UK-wins-funding-for-a-trial-to-visualise-big-data-|title=Skanska UK wins funding for a trial to visualise big data {{!}} www.skanska.co.uk|website=www.skanska.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-11-01}} The lead investor behind the company is an early stage venture capital fund Sussex Place Ventures owned by [[London Business School]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.buildingconstructiondesign.co.uk/news/3d-repo-virtual-reality-project-shortlisted-for-british-construction-industry-award/|title=3d repo virtual reality project shortlisted for british construction industry award {{!}} netMAGmedia Ltd|website=www.buildingconstructiondesign.co.uk|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-10-31}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.spventures.com/company/3d-repo/|title=3D Repo {{!}} Sussex Place Ventures|work=Sussex Place Ventures|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-GB}} 3D Repo is an organizational member of [[British Computer Society]], the Chartered Institute for IT.{{Cite news|url=http://3drepo.org/3d-repo-becomes-member-of-british-computer-society/|title=3D Repo becomes member of British Computer Society|work=3D Repo - Collaborative online BIM platform|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.bcs.org/content/conEvent/9740|title=3D Repo - Non-linear Version Control using NoSQL MongoDB followed by AGM {{!}} Events List {{!}} Events calendar {{!}} Events {{!}} BCS - The Chartered Institute for IT|website=www.bcs.org|language=en|access-date=2017-11-01}} In 2015, 3D Repo was named one of top 20 tech innovators in the UK. == History == === Academic research === 3D Repo version control system—still in its early stages of doctoral research—was originally demonstrated at the joint [[SIGGRAPH]] and Web3D conference in [[Los Angeles]], [[United States]] in August 2012 featuring the [[London King's Cross railway station#Restoration|King's Cross Station Redevelopment]] project by [[Arup Group|Arup]].{{Cite journal|last=Doboš|first=Jozef|last2=Steed|first2=Anthony|date=2012|title=3D Revision Control Framework|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2338714.2338736|journal=Proceedings of the 17th International Conference on 3D Web Technology|series=Web3D '12|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=121–129|doi=10.1145/2338714.2338736|isbn=9781450314329}}{{Cite journal|last=Doboš|first=Jozef|last2=Steed|first2=Anthony|date=2012|title=3D Diff: An Interactive Approach to Mesh Differencing and Conflict Resolution|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2343045.2343064|journal=ACM SIGGRAPH 2012 Talks|series=SIGGRAPH '12|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=15:1–15:1|doi=10.1145/2343045.2343064|isbn=9781450316835}} Later that year, 3D Repo attended an invited lecture at [[German Research Centre for Artificial Intelligence]] (DFKI) in [[Saarbrücken]], [[Germany]] which led to a collaboration and development of the first [[Representational state transfer|REST]] [[Application programming interface|API]] for the system.{{Cite web|url=http://domino.mpi-inf.mpg.de/internet/events.nsf/0/7941CF10F149CE95C1257A8D00513219|title=Campus Event Calendar: Jozef Dobos (10/08/2012 in D 3 2/VizCenter, DFKI)|website=domino.mpi-inf.mpg.de|language=en|access-date=2017-10-31}}{{Cite journal|last=Doboš|first=Jozef|last2=Sons|first2=Kristian|last3=Rubinstein|first3=Dmitri|last4=Slusallek|first4=Philipp|last5=Steed|first5=Anthony|date=2013|title=XML3DRepo: A REST API for Version Controlled 3D Assets on the Web|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2466533.2466537|journal=Proceedings of the 18th International Conference on 3D Web Technology|series=Web3D '13|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=47–55|doi=10.1145/2466533.2466537|isbn=9781450321334}} The front-end visualization was programmed in XML3D and was featured at Web3D 2013 in [[San Sebastián]], [[Spain]]. The main scientific advancement was the introduction of externalized web 3D resources in various encodings that enabled interactivity and prevented web browsers from becoming unresponsive while loading very large 3D models over the [[Internet]].{{Citation|last=3drepoorg|title=XML3DRepo: A REST API for Version Controlled 3D Assets on the Web|date=2013-06-17|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-1BTzVgxI5I&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-10-31}} [[SIGGRAPH#SIGGRAPH Asia|SIGGRAPH Asia]] 2012 in [[Singapore]] also introduced a native Android application and the very first 3D differencing tool ''Interactive 3D Diff''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.3ders.org/articles/20121105-3d-repo-open-source-revision-control-framework-for-large-3d-models.html|title=3D Repo: open source Revision Control Framework for large 3D models|work=3ders.org|access-date=2017-11-01|language=en-US}}{{Cite journal|last=Doboš|first=Jozef|last2=Simondetti|first2=Alvise|last3=Steed|first3=Anthony|date=2012|title=Visualizing 3D Models in Aid of Public Consultation|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2407696.2407705|journal=SIGGRAPH Asia 2012 Symposium on Apps|series=SA '12|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=9:1–9:1|doi=10.1145/2407696.2407705|isbn=9781450319164}}{{Cite journal|last=Doboš|first=Jozef|last2=Steed|first2=Anthony|date=2012|title=3D Diff: An Interactive Approach to Mesh Differencing and Conflict Resolution|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2407746.2407766|journal=SIGGRAPH Asia 2012 Technical Briefs|series=SA '12|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=20:1–20:4|doi=10.1145/2407746.2407766|isbn=9781450319157}} Subsequent collaboration with Prof Niloy Mitra at [[University College London]] led to the development of a reverse engineering system ''3D Timeline'' presented at [[Eurographics]] 2014 in [[Strasbourg]], [[France]].{{Cite journal|last=Doboš|first=Jozef|last2=Mitra|first2=Niloy J.|last3=Steed|first3=Anthony|date=2014-05-01|title=3D Timeline: Reverse engineering of a part-based provenance from consecutive 3D models|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/cgf.12311/abstract|journal=Computer Graphics Forum|language=en|volume=33|issue=2|pages=135–144|doi=10.1111/cgf.12311|issn=1467-8659}} Unlike Interactive 3D Diff which required prior correspondence information, i.e. matching object-level identifiers between revisions, 3D Timeline reverse engineered the relationships and changes between 3D components over multiple revisions without prior correspondence.{{Citation|last=3drepoorg|title=3D Timeline: Reverse Engineering of a Part-based Provenance from Consecutive 3D Models (EG 2014)|date=2014-01-23|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oTmnm1sLf14&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-10-31}} === Commercial development === Based on the potential commercial impact of 3D Repo, the project was awarded VEIV Advance Scholarship{{Cite web|url=http://veiv.cs.ucl.ac.uk/materials-for-students-and-supervisors/forms-guides/201-veiv-advance-scholarship|title=UCL Centre VEIV Advance Scholarship|last=Steed|first=Anthony|website=veiv.cs.ucl.ac.uk|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-10-31}} in order to devise a business plan. This was nominated for the [[Royal Academy of Engineering]] ERA Foundation Entrepreneurs Award in December 2013.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cs.ucl.ac.uk/news/?tx_ttnews%5Btt_news%5D=1048&cHash=69bc396986c489590f153cc5e636b5ab|title=CS EngD VEIV Student shortlisted for Entrepreneurs Award|website=www.cs.ucl.ac.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-10-31}} A commercial company was registered in April 2014{{Cite web|url=https://beta.companieshouse.gov.uk/company/09014101|title=3D REPO LTD - Overview (free company information from Companies House)|website=beta.companieshouse.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-10-31}} following the award of an [[Innovate UK]] Smart grant which also helped to secure initial angel funding.{{Cite web|url=https://innovateuk.blog.gov.uk/2016/02/18/meet-our-customers-3d-repo/|title=Meet our customers - 3D Repo - Innovate UK|website=innovateuk.blog.gov.uk|language=en|access-date=2017-10-31}} In the second half of 2014, the project was seconded to [[Balfour Beatty]] via the Breakthrough Information Technology Exchange programme applying the new technology to the [[London Olympic Stadium]] Transformation project.{{Cite news|url=http://www.biteimpact.org/bite-goes-olympic-stadium/|title=BITE goes to the Olympic Stadium - Welcome to BITE - Breakthrough Information Technology Exchange|date=2015-09-09|work=Welcome to BITE - Breakthrough Information Technology Exchange|access-date=2017-11-01|language=en-US}} This led to the development and application of [[Virtual reality]] for [[health and safety]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.wearecallidus.com/opinion/virtual-reality-health-safety-training/|title=Virtual reality ready to redefine health & safety in construction industry|date=2017-02-22|work=Callidus Health & Safety|access-date=2017-11-01|language=en-GB}} training on the M5 [[Smart motorway|Smart Motorway]] in the UK which was nominated for [[British Construction Industry Awards]] in 2017. In 2015, 3D Repo was also invited to join the third cohort of Cognicity Challenge by [[Canary Wharf Group]].{{Cite news|url=http://group.canarywharf.com/media/press-releases/cognicity-challenge-tailors-third-group-of-smart-city-tech-accelerator-to-new-phase-at-canary-wharf-200415/|title=Cognicity Challenge tailors third group of smart city tech accelerator to new phase at Canary Wharf - 20.04.15 - Canary Wharf Group|work=Canary Wharf Group|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}} The challenge consisted of an intensive twelve-week incubation programme designed to identify and solve construction problems faced by Canary Wharf in collaboration with [[Intel]]. The resulting [[Building information modeling|Building Information Modeling]] platform 3drepo.io won the ''Virtual Design and Construction'' category, a £50,000 cash prize and a paid pilot deploying the solution to the [[Wood Wharf]] development.{{Cite news|url=http://group.canarywharf.com/media/press-releases/canary-wharf-group-lays-the-foundations-for-smarter-city-080715/|title=Canary Wharf Group Lays the Foundations for a Smarter City - 08.07.15 - Canary Wharf Group|work=Canary Wharf Group|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.eitdigital.eu/newsroom/news/article/3d-repo-wins-the-cognicity-challenge-by-canary-wharf-group/|title=3D Repo wins the Cognicity challenge by Canary Wharf Group|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en}} This enabled design coordination and federation of large 3D models via modern [[WebGL]]-enabled web browsers.{{Citation|last=3D Repo|title=Wood Wharf Development in 3D Repo|date=2016-11-24|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kAnJqdSHv2Y&feature=youtu.be|accessdate=2017-10-31}} The inner workings of the platform utilizing the X3DOM renderer developed in collaboration with [[Fraunhofer Institute]] were presented at the 20th anniversary Web3D conference in [[Heraklion]], [[Greece]].{{Cite journal|last=Scully|first=Timothy|last2=Doboš|first2=Jozef|last3=Sturm|first3=Timo|last4=Jung|first4=Yvonne|date=2015|title=3Drepo.Io: Building the Next Generation Web3D Repository with AngularJS and X3DOM|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2775292.2775312|journal=Proceedings of the 20th International Conference on 3D Web Technology|series=Web3D '15|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=235–243|doi=10.1145/2775292.2775312|isbn=9781450336475}} The platform was subsequently expanded with experimental streaming capability using [[glTF]] data format{{Cite journal|last=Scully|first=Timothy|last2=Friston|first2=Sebastian|last3=Fan|first3=Carmen|last4=Doboš|first4=Jozef|last5=Steed|first5=Anthony|date=2016|title=glTF Streaming from 3D Repo to X3DOM|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/2945292.2945297|journal=Proceedings of the 21st International Conference on Web3D Technology|series=Web3D '16|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=7–15|doi=10.1145/2945292.2945297|isbn=9781450344289}} developed in collaboration with [[University College London]]. Further advanced cloud security provisions were developed in collaboration with [[British Telecom]]{{Cite news|url=http://3drepo.org/projects/3d-repo-in-a-secure-cloud-environment-a-case-study/|title=3D Repo in a Secure Cloud Environment; a Case Study|work=3D Repo - Collaborative online BIM platform|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}} In 2017, 3D Repo unveiled version 2.0 based on the [[Unity (game engine)|Unity]] game engine.{{Cite news|url=https://csengineermag.com/3d-repo-releases-version-2-0-cross-platform-bim-geospatial-collaboration-software/|title=3D Repo releases version 2.0 of cross-platform BIM and geospatial collaboration software - Civil + Structural Engineer magazine|date=2017-10-26|work=Civil + Structural Engineer magazine|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}} This technological interconnection received the Best Paper Award{{Cite news|url=http://3drepo.org/best-paper-award-at-web3d-2017/|title=Best Paper Award at Web3D 2017|work=3D Repo - Collaborative online BIM platform|access-date=2017-10-31|language=en-US}} at Web3D 2017 in [[Brisbane]], [[Australia]].{{Cite journal|last=Friston|first=Sebastian|last2=Fan|first2=Carmen|last3=Doboš|first3=Jozef|last4=Scully|first4=Timothy|last5=Steed|first5=Anthony|date=2017|title=3DRepo4Unity: Dynamic Loading of Version Controlled 3D Assets into the Unity Game Engine|url=http://doi.acm.org/10.1145/3055624.3075941|journal=Proceedings of the 22Nd International Conference on 3D Web Technology|series=Web3D '17|location=New York, NY, USA|publisher=ACM|pages=15:1–15:9|doi=10.1145/3055624.3075941|isbn=9781450349550}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Software]] [[Category:Software by company]]

revision.comment: use cite magazine for Art in America
revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Use American English|date=November 2014}} '''''4′33″''''' (pronounced "'''Four minutes, thirty-three seconds'''" or just "'''Four thirty-three'''")Solomon 1998/2002. is a three-[[movement (music)|movement]] compositionPritchett, Kuhn, Grove.Kostelanetz 2003, 69–71, 86, 105, 198, 218, 231. by American [[Experimental music|experimental]] composer [[John Cage]] (1912–1992). It was composed in 1952, for any instrument or combination of instruments, and the score instructs the performer(s) not to play their instrument(s) during the entire duration of the piece throughout the three movements. The piece consists of the sounds of the environment that the listeners hear while it is performed,Kostelanetz 2003, 69–70. although it is commonly perceived as "four minutes thirty-three seconds of silence".Fetterman 1996, 69.Lienhard 2003, 254. The title of the piece refers to the total length in minutes and seconds of a given performance, ''4′33″'' being the total length of the first public performance.Published score, Edition Peters 6777. Conceived around 1947–48, while the composer was working on ''[[Sonatas and Interludes]]'', ''4′33″'' became for Cage the epitome of his idea that any sounds may constitute [[Definition of music|music]].{{cite web| url = http://www.classicalnotes.net/columns/silence.html| title = John Cage and the Avant-Garde: The Sounds of Silence| accessdate = April 4, 2007| last = Gutmann| first = Peter| authorlink = Peter Gutmann (journalist)| year = 1999}} It was also a reflection of the influence of [[Zen Buddhism]], which Cage studied since the late 1940s. In a 1982 interview, and on numerous other occasions, Cage stated that ''4′33″'' was, in his opinion, his most important work.Kostelanetz 2003, 70. ''[[The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians]]'' describes ''4′33″'' as Cage's "most famous and controversial creation". ==History of composition== ===Background and influences=== Silence played a major role in several of Cage's works composed before ''4′33″''. The ''Duet for Two Flutes'' (1934), composed when Cage was 22, opens with silence, and silence was an important structural element in some of the ''[[Sonatas and Interludes]]'' (1946–48), ''[[Music of Changes]]'' (1951) and ''Two Pastorales'' (1951). The ''Concerto for prepared piano and orchestra'' (1951) closes with an extended silence, and ''Waiting'' (1952), a piano piece composed just a few months before ''4′33″'', consists of long silences framing a single, short [[ostinato]] pattern. Furthermore, in his songs ''[[The Wonderful Widow of Eighteen Springs]]'' (1942) and ''[[A Flower]]'' (1950) Cage directs the pianist to play a closed instrument, which may be understood as a metaphor of silence.Revill 1993, 162. The first time Cage mentioned the idea of a piece composed entirely of silence was during a 1947 (or 1948) lecture at [[Vassar College]], ''A Composer's Confessions''. Cage told the audience that he had "several new desires", one of which was
to compose a piece of uninterrupted silence and sell it to [[Muzak Holdings|Muzak Co]]. It will be three or four-and-a-half minutes long—those being the standard lengths of "canned" music and its title will be ''Silent Prayer''. It will open with a single idea which I will attempt to make as seductive as the color and shape and fragrance of a flower. The ending will approach imperceptibility.Pritchett 1993, 59, 138.
At the time, however, Cage felt that such a piece would be "incomprehensible in the Western context," and was reluctant to write it down: "I didn't wish it to appear, even to me, as something easy to do or as a joke. I wanted to mean it utterly and be able to live with it."Revill 1993, 164. Painter [[Alfred Leslie]] recalls Cage presenting a "one-minute-of-silence talk" in front of a window during the late 1940s, while visiting Studio 35 at [[New York University]].{{cite magazine |author=Stein, Judith |year=2009 |title=Interview: Alfred Leslie |magazine=[[Art in America]] |issue=January 2009 |page=92 |url=http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/features/interview-alfred-leslie/ |access-date=October 8, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101204172036/http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/features/interview-alfred-leslie/ |archive-date=December 4, 2010 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} In 1951, Cage visited the [[anechoic chamber]] at [[Harvard University]]. An anechoic chamber is a room designed in such a way that the walls, ceiling and floor absorb all sounds made in the room, rather than reflecting them as echoes. Such a chamber is also externally sound-proofed. Cage entered the chamber expecting to hear silence, but he wrote later, "I heard two sounds, one high and one low. When I described them to the engineer in charge, he informed me that the high one was my [[nervous system]] in operation, the low one my blood in [[circulatory system|circulation]]."{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sask/features/artist/journal2.html |title=A few notes about silence and John Cage |date=November 24, 2004 |publisher=CBC.ca |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060212191730/http://www.cbc.ca/sask/features/artist/journal2.html |archivedate=February 12, 2006 }} Cage had gone to a place where he expected total silence, and yet heard sound. "Until I die there will be sounds. And they will continue following my death. One need not fear about the future of music."Cage 1961, 8. The realization as he saw it of the impossibility of silence led to the composition of ''4′33″''. Another cited influence for this piece came from the field of the visual arts. Cage's friend and sometimes colleague [[Robert Rauschenberg]] had produced, in 1951, a series of white paintings, seemingly "blank" canvases (though painted with white house paint) that in fact change according to varying light conditions in the rooms in which they were hung, the shadows of people in the room and so on. This inspired Cage to use a similar idea, as he later stated, "Actually what pushed me into it was not guts but the example of Robert Rauschenberg. His white paintings [...] when I saw those, I said, 'Oh yes, I must. Otherwise I'm lagging, otherwise music is lagging'."Kostelanetz 2003, 71. In an introduction to an article called On Robert Rauschenberg, Artist, and His Works, John Cage writes "To Whom It May Concern: The white paintings came first; my silent piece came later."Cage, John. Silence: Lectures and Writings. Middletown, CT: Wesleyan UP, 1961. Print. ===Precursors=== Compositions that, like ''4′33″'', include no sounds produced by the performer, were conceived by a number of composers and writers before Cage. Examples include the following: * [[Alphonse Allais]]'s 1897 ''Funeral March for the Obsequies of a Deaf Man'', consisting of twenty-four blank measures.Allais, Alphonse. 1897. ''[[Album primo-avrilesque]]'', p. 23-26. [http://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b86263801/f29.image Available online.] Allais was an associate of [[Erik Satie]], and given Cage's profound admiration for Satie, it is possible that Cage was inspired by the ''Funeral March''. When asked, Cage claimed he was unaware of Allais's composition at the time.Dickinson 1991, 406. * In [[Gaston Leroux]]'s 1903 novel ''La Double Vie de Théophraste Longuet'', silent concerts are given by the Talpa people.Leroux, Gaston. 1903. ''La Double Vie de Théophraste Longuet''. [http://www.ebooksgratuits.com/pdf/leroux_double_vie_t_longuet.pdf Available online.] * [[Erwin Schulhoff]]'s 1919 "In futurum", a movement from the ''Fünf Pittoresken'' for piano. The Czech composer's meticulously notated composition is made up entirely of rests.Bek, Grove. * In [[Harold Acton]]'s 1928 book ''Cornelian'' a musician conducts "performances consisting largely of silence".Carpenter, Humphrey. 1990. ''The Brideshead Generation: Evelyn Waugh and His Friends'', 153. Houghton Mifflin. {{ISBN|978-0-395-44142-8}} * In 1947, jazz musician [[Dave Tough]] joked that he was writing a play in which "A string quartet is playing the most advanced music ever written. It's made up entirely of rests. [...] Suddenly, the viola man jumps up in a rage and shakes his bow at the first violin. 'Lout,' he screams, 'you played that last measure wrong.'""New Jazz: 'All or Nothing at All'" (March 16, 1947) ''The Washington Post''. p. S7. * [[Yves Klein]]'s 1949 ''Monotone-Silence Symphony'' (informally ''The Monotone Symphony'', conceived 1947–48), an orchestral forty-minute piece whose second and last movement is a twenty-minute silenceSee sources and recordings at the [[Yves Klein]] article. (the first movement being an unvarying twenty minute drone). {{further|List of silent musical compositions}} The musicologist [[Richard Taruskin]] has argued that ''4′33″'' is an example of [[Automatic behavior|automatism]]. Since the [[Romantic Era]] composers have been striving to produce music that could be separated from any social connections, transcending the boundaries of time and space. In automatism, composers wish to completely remove both the composers and the artist from the process of creation. This is motivated by the belief that what we think of as "self-expression" is really just an infusion of the art with the social standards that we have been subjected to since birth. Therefore, the only way to achieve truth is to remove the artist from the process of creation. Cage achieves that by employing chance (e.g., use of the ''[[I Ching]]'', or tossing coins) to make compositional decisions. In ''4′33″'', neither artist nor composer has any impact on the piece, so that Cage has no way of controlling what ambient sounds will be heard by the audience.Taruskin 2009, 55. ===Premiere and reception=== {| class="toccolours" style="float: right; margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 2em; font-size: 85%; color:black; width:30em; max-width: 40%;" cellspacing="5" | style="text-align: left;" | They missed the point. There's no such thing as silence. What they thought was silence, because they didn't know how to listen, was full of accidental sounds. You could hear the wind stirring outside during the first movement. During the second, raindrops began pattering the roof, and during the third the people themselves made all kinds of interesting sounds as they talked or walked out. |- | style="text-align: right;" | — [[John Cage]] speaking about the premiere of ''4′33″'' |} The premiere of the three-movement ''4′33″'' was given by [[David Tudor]] on August 29, 1952, in [[Maverick Concert Hall]], [[Woodstock, New York]], as part of a recital of contemporary piano music. The audience saw him sit at the piano and, to mark the beginning of the piece, close the keyboard lid. Some time later he opened it briefly, to mark the end of the first movement. This process was repeated for the second and third movements.The actions of Tudor in the first performance are often misdescribed so that the lid is explained as being open during the movements. Cage's handwritten score (produced after the first performance) states that the lid was closed during the movements, and opened to mark the spaces between. The piece remains controversial to this day, and is seen as challenging the very [[definition of music]].{{Citation needed|date=September 2017}} In defining [[noise music]] and its value, Paul Hegarty in ''Noise/Music: A History'' (2007) contends that Cage's ''4′33″'' represents the beginning of [[noise music]] proper. For Hegarty, noise music, as with ''4′33″'', is that music made up of incidental sounds that represent perfectly the tension between "desirable" sound (properly played musical notes) and undesirable "noise" that make up all noise music.Paul Hegarty, ''Noise/Music: A History'' (2007) Continuum International Publishing Group{{Page needed|date=August 2010}} ''4′33″'' challenges, or rather exploits to a radical extent, the social regiments of the modern concert life etiquette, experimenting on unsuspecting concert-goers to prove an important point. First, the choice of a prestigious venue and the social status of the composer and the performers automatically heightens audience's expectations for the piece. As a result, the listener is more focused, giving Cage's ''4′33″'' the same amount of attention (or perhaps even more) as if it were Beethoven's Ninth.Taruskin 2009, 71. Thus, even before the performance, the reception of the work is already predetermined by the social setup of the concert. Furthermore, the audience's behavior is limited by the rules and regulation of the concert hall; they will quietly sit and listen to 4′33” of ambient noise. It is not easy to get a large group of people to listen to ambient noise for nearly five minutes, unless they are regulated by the concert hall etiquette. The second point made by ''4′33″'' concerns duration. According to Cage, duration is the essential building block of all of music. This distinction is motivated by the fact that duration is the only element shared by both silence and sound. As a result, the underlying structure of any musical piece consists of an organized sequence of "time buckets".Taruskin 2009, 56. They could be filled with either sounds, silence or noise; where neither of these elements is absolutely necessary for completeness. In the spirit of his teacher [[Arnold Schoenberg|Schoenberg]], Cage managed to emancipate the silence and the noise to make it an acceptable or perhaps even integral part of his music composition. ''4′33″'' serves as a radical and extreme illustration of this concept, asking that if the time buckets are the only necessary parts of the musical composition, then what stops the composer from filling them with no intentional sounds? The third point is that the work of music is defined not only by its content but also by the behavior it elicits from the audience. In the case of Stravinsky's ''[[The Rite of Spring|Rite of Spring]]'', this would consist of widespread dissatisfaction leading up to violent riots. In Cage's ''4′33″'', the audience felt cheated by having to listen to no composed sounds from the performer. Nevertheless, in ''4′33″'' the audience contributed the bulk of the musical material of the piece. Since the piece consists of exclusively ambient noise, the audience's behavior, their whispers and movements, are essential elements that fill the above-mentioned time buckets. In a 2013 [[TED Talk]], philosophy professor Julian Dodd argues that ''4′33″'' is witty [[conceptual art]], but does not meet the criteria for it to count as music, instead challenging the listener to question what the nature of music is.{{YouTube|id=WTCVnKROlos&t=13m38s|title=Is John Cage's 4′33″ music? Prof. Julian Dodd at TEDxUniversityOfManchester}}, June 8, 2013 In a 2013 TED Talk, psychologist Paul Bloom puts forward ''4′33″'' as one example to show that knowing about the origin of something influences our opinion about it as "that silence is different from other forms of silence".{{cite web|url=http://www.ted.com/talks/paul_bloom_the_origins_of_pleasure?language=en#|title=Paul Bloom: The origins of pleasure - Talk Video - TED.com|author =Paul Bloom|work=ted.com}} ===Versions of the score=== Several versions of the score exist:This paragraph summarizes some of the findings from Solomon 1998/2002. There are four known later versions, one of which is in the [[New York Public Library]].Carol Vogel (November 15, 2012), [https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/16/arts/design/a-glenn-ligon-at-national-gallery-john-cage-at-moma.html A Moment of Silence at MoMA] ''[[The New York Times]]''. * The original Woodstock manuscript (August 1952): conventional notation, dedicated to [[David Tudor]]. This manuscript is currently lost. Tudor's attempt at re-creating the original score is reproduced in Fetterman 1996, 74. * The Kremen manuscript (1953): graphic, space-time notation, dedicated to [[Irwin Kremen]]. The movements of the piece are rendered as space between long vertical lines; a tempo indication is provided (60), and at the end of each movement the time is indicated in minutes and seconds.Fetterman 1996, 76–78. Edition Peters No. 6777a. Kremen was given the score by Cage on June 5, 1953, for his 28th birthday. The score was later purchased for the [[Museum of Modern Art]] by [[Henry R. Kravis]] in honor of his wife, [[Marie-Josée Drouin]], the museum's president. * The so-called ''First Tacet Edition'': a typewritten score, lists the three movements using Roman numbers, with the word "[[Tacet|TACET]]" underneath each. A note by Cage describes the first performance and mentions that "the work may be performed by any instrumentalist or combination of instrumentalists and last any length of time." Edition Peters No. 6777 (out of print). * The so-called ''Second Tacet Edition'': same as the First, except that it is printed in Cage's calligraphy, and the explanatory note mentions the Kremen manuscript. Edition Peters No. 6777 (i.e., it carries the same catalog number as the first ''Tacet Edition'') Additionally, a facsimile, reduced in size, of the Kremen manuscript, appeared in July 1967 in ''Source'' 1, no. 2:46–54; the ''First Tacet Edition'' is described in Nyman 1974, 3, but it is not reproduced in that book. There is some discrepancy between the lengths of individual movements of the premiere performance, specified in different versions of the score. The Woodstock printed program specifies the lengths 30″, 2′23″ and 1′40″, as does the Kremen manuscript, and presumably the original manuscript had the same indications. However, in the ''First Tacet Edition'' Cage writes that at the premiere the timings were 33″, 2′40″ and 1′20″. In the ''Second Tacet Edition'' he adds that after the premier a copy has been made for Irwin Kremen, in which the lengths of the movements were 30″, 2′23″ and 1′40″. The causes of this discrepancy are not currently understood, the original manuscript being still lost. ===''4′33″ No. 2''=== In 1962, Cage wrote '''''0′00″''''', which is also referred to as '''''4′33″ No. 2'''''. The directions originally consisted of one sentence: "In a situation provided with maximum amplification, perform a disciplined action." At the first performance Cage had to write that sentence. The second performance added four new qualifications to the directions: "the performer should allow any interruptions of the action, the action should fulfill an obligation to others, the same action should not be used in more than one performance, and should not be the performance of a musical composition." ===''One3''=== In late 1989, three years before his death, Cage revisited the idea of ''4′33″'' one last time. He composed ''One3'', the full title of which is ''One3 = 4′33″ (0′00″) + [[Image:GClef.svg|9px]]''. As in all [[Number Pieces|number pieces]], "One" refers to the number of performers required. The score instructs the performer to build a [[Sound reinforcement system|sound system]] in the concert hall, so that "the whole hall is on the edge of [[Audio feedback|feedback]], without actually feeding back." The content of the piece is the electronically amplified sound of the hall and the audience.{{cite web |url= http://johncage.org/pp/John-Cage-Work-Detail.cfm?work_ID=299 |title= One3 = 4'33" (0'0") + [G clef] |website= John Cage |access-date= 25 Mar 2017}} ==Performances and recordings== ''4′33″'' has been recorded on several occasions: [[Frank Zappa]] recorded it as part of ''A Chance Operation: The John Cage Tribute'', on the Koch label, 1993; in 2002, [[James Tenney]] performed ''4′33″'' at Rudolf Schindler's historic [[Kings Road House]] in celebration of the work's 50th anniversary.Tenney's recording is archived on line via The Society for the Activation of Social Space through Art and Sound (SASSAS) Several performances of ''4′33″'' including a "techno remix" by [[New Waver]] were broadcast on Australian radio station [[ABC Classic FM]], as part of a program exploring "sonic responses" to Cage's work.{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/classic/daily/stories/s376971.htm|title=ABC Classic FM music details for 11 July 2001|access-date=January 7, 2006|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090425183449/http://www.abc.net.au/classic/daily/stories/s376971.htm|archive-date=April 25, 2009|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}{{cite book|last=Kouvaras|first=Linda|title=Loading the Silence: Australian Sound Art in the Post-Digital Age|year=2013|publisher=Ashgate Publishing|location=Farnham|isbn=9781409441564}} The Swedish electronic band [[Covenant (band)|Covenant]] concluded their 2000 album ''[[United States of Mind (album)|United States of Mind]]'' with a rendition of ''4′33″'' entitled "You Can Make Your Own Music".{{cite book|last=Reed|first=Alexander S.|date=2013|title=Assimilate: A Critical History of Industrial Music|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=43|isbn=9780199339624|quote=Industrial trio Covenant conclude their 2000 album ''United States of Mind'' with four minutes and thirty-three soundless seconds (on a track called "You Can Make Your Own Music"), nodding slyly to composer John Cage, whose silent ''4’33”'' of 1952 may be the ultimate open question of what constitutes music; but the other ten songs on Covenant's album are more or less all pop tunes with scarcely a trace of Cage's vital indeterminacy.}} On January 16, 2004, at the [[Barbican Centre]] in London, the [[BBC Symphony Orchestra]] gave the UK's first orchestral performance of this work. The performance was broadcast live on BBC Radio 3, and one of the main challenges was that the station's emergency backup systems are designed to switch on and play music whenever apparent silence ([[dead air]]) lasting longer than a preset duration is detected. They had to be switched off for this performance.{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/pressoffice/pressreleases/stories/2004/01_january/12/john_cage.shtml|title=BBC Press Office, Cage Uncaged|date=February 21, 2007}} A [[tongue-in-cheek]] version was recorded by the staff of the UK ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' newspaper on January 16, 2004.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2004/jan/16/1?INTCMP=SRCH|title=Guardian recording of 4′33|date=January 16, 2004 | location=London|work=The Guardian}} In 2004, the work was voted to be number 40 in the ABC radio's [[Classic 100 piano (ABC)|Classic 100 piano countdown]].{{cite web |title=The Classic 100 Piano |url=http://www.abc.net.au/classic/classic100/piano.htm |publisher=[[ABC Classic FM]] |accessdate=25 Mar 2017}} A silence of four minutes and thirty-three seconds appears as the penultimate track of the 2009 [[Living Colour]] album [[The Chair in the Doorway]].{{cite web |title=Living Colour – The Chair In The Doorway|url=https://www.discogs.com/Living-Colour-The-Chair-In-The-Doorway/master/236886 |publisher=[[Discogs]] |accessdate=17 May 2017}} On December 5, 2010, an international simultaneous performance of Cage's ''4′33″'' took place involving over 200 performers, amateur and professional musicians, and artists. The global orchestra, conducted live by Bob Dickinson, former member of post-punk group [[Magazine (band)|Magazine]], via video link, performed the piece in support of the Cage Against The Machine campaign to bring ''4′33″'' to Christmas number 1 in 2010. A second performance took place on December 12, 2010.{{cite news|title=We're pitching the silence of John Cage against the noise of Simon Cowell|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/turner-prize/8195729/Were-pitching-the-silence-of-John-Cage-against-the-noise-of-Simon-Cowell.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=December 11, 2010|accessdate=December 17, 2010|location=London|first=Norman|last=Lebrecht|authorlink=Norman Lebrecht| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110121140124/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/art/turner-prize/8195729/Were-pitching-the-silence-of-John-Cage-against-the-noise-of-Simon-Cowell.html| archivedate= January 21, 2011 | deadurl= no}} On November 17, 2015, ''[[The Late Show with Stephen Colbert]]'' uploaded a video of this piece being performed by a [[cat]], showing that its performer isn't required to be human.{{YouTube|YpZekJDrbvc|''Late Show with Stephen Colbert''; Nola the Cat Performs John Cage's 4′33″}} ==2010 UK Christmas Number One campaign== In the week leading up to Christmas 2010, a [[Facebook page]] was created to encourage people in the UK to buy a new rendition of ''4′33″'' {{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/cageagainstthemachine|title=John Cage's ''4′33"'' for Christmas Number One 2010 |publisher=[[Facebook]]|accessdate=October 28, 2010 |date=December 2009}} in the hope that it would prevent the winner of the [[The X Factor (UK series 7)|seventh series of ''The X Factor'']] from topping the [[UK Singles Chart]] and achieving the [[List of Christmas number one singles (UK)|Christmas number one]].{{cite web|title=Cowell’s second festive humiliation?|first=Ben|last=Gilbert|url=http://new.uk.music.yahoo.com/blogs/behind_the_music/27330/cowells-second-festive-humiliation/|publisher=[[Yahoo! Music]]|date=October 4, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101018232218/http://new.uk.music.yahoo.com/blogs/behind_the_music/27330/cowells-second-festive-humiliation/| archivedate= October 18, 2010 | deadurl= no}} The page was inspired by an [[Tracy Morter|earlier campaign]] in which a Facebook page set up by Jon and Tracey Morter prompted people to buy "[[Killing in the Name]]" by American rap metal protest group [[Rage Against the Machine]] in the week before Christmas 2009,{{Cite news|title=Sound of silence vies to be Christmas number one|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopmusic/8067341/Sound-of-silence-vies-to-be-Christmas-number-one.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=October 16, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2010|location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101019034320/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandpopmusic/8067341/Sound-of-silence-vies-to-be-Christmas-number-one.html| archivedate= October 19, 2010 | deadurl= no}} and has therefore been dubbed "Cage Against the Machine".{{Cite news|title=Silence bids for Christmas number one|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/1015/breaking30.html|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|date=October 15, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101027093238/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/breaking/2010/1015/breaking30.html| archivedate= October 27, 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{Cite news|title=At time of writing, Cage Against The Machine has almost 16,000 followers on Facebook|first=Andrew|last=Eaton|url=http://scotlandonsunday.scotsman.com/features/Andrew-Eaton-39At-time-of.6562712.jp|format=JP|newspaper=[[Scotland on Sunday]]|date=October 5, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2010}} The creators of the Facebook page hoped that reaching number one would help to promote the piece and "make December 25 'a silent night'."{{Cite news|title=Shhh! It could REALLY be a silent night this Christmas... if Facebook has anything to do with it |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1320787/Facebooks-silent-Christmas-1-Cage-Against-The-Machine-John-Cage.html |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |date=October 15, 2010 |accessdate=October 28, 2010 |location=London |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120801142931/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1320787/Facebooks-silent-Christmas-1-Cage-Against-The-Machine-John-Cage.html |archivedate=August 1, 2012 |deadurl=no }} {{as of|2017|September}}, the Facebook page has over 65,000 likes.{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/cageagainstthemachine|title=JOHN CAGE'S 4'33" FOR CHRISTMAS NUMBER ONE 2010|last=|first=|date=|website=Facebook|publisher=Facebook|accessdate=September 26, 2017}} The campaign received support from several celebrities. It first came into prominence after it was mentioned by British [[science writer]] [[Ben Goldacre]] on his [[Twitter]] profile.{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/bengoldacre/status/18942556433|title=John Cage's ''4′33"'' for Xmas ...|first=Ben|last=Goldacre|authorlink=Ben_Goldacre|date=July 19, 2010|publisher=[[Twitter]]|accessdate=October 28, 2010}} Within two weeks, British newspaper ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' reported that the Facebook page had been backed by more than 3,000 members.{{Cite news|title=Sound of silence to beat 'Si's X Factor'|first=Colin|last=Robertson|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/showbiz/tv/x_factor/3076063/Campaign-starts-for-a-silent-composition-to-beat-X-Factor-to-the-Christmas-number-one.html|newspaper=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|date=July 31, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2010|location=London}} One of several similar campaigns, the Facebook page was called "the only effort this year with a hope of [reaching Number One]" by ''[[The Guardian]]'' journalist Tom Ewing in September.{{Cite news|title=John Cage's ''4′33"'': the festive sound of a defeated Simon Cowell|first=Tom|last=Ewing|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2010/sep/30/christmas-no1-facebook-campaign|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=September 30, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2010|location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101007002256/http://www.guardian.co.uk/media/2010/sep/30/christmas-no1-facebook-campaign| archivedate= October 7, 2010 | deadurl= no}} [[XFM]] DJ [[Eddy Temple-Morris]] also voiced his support on his [[blog]],{{cite web|url=http://eddysays.thecmuwebsite.com/post/Once-more-unto-the-breach-dear-friends.aspx|title=Once more unto the breach dear friends|first=Eddy|last=Temple-Morris|authorlink=Eddy_Temple-Morris|date=October 27, 2010|accessdate=October 28, 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20101112162938/http://eddysays.thecmuwebsite.com/post/Once-more-unto-the-breach-dear-friends.aspx| archivedate= November 12, 2010 | deadurl= no}} as did Luke Bainbridge.{{cite news |title=Why I'm backing Cage Against the Machine for Christmas No 1|author =Luke Bainbridge |url= https://www.theguardian.com/music/musicblog/2010/dec/13/cage-against-machine-christmas-no-1|newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=December 13, 2010 |accessdate=December 13, 2010 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110110201052/http://www.guardian.co.uk/music/musicblog/2010/dec/13/cage-against-machine-christmas-no-1| archivedate= January 10, 2011 | deadurl= no}} This version of Cage's work failed to make number 1, but charted at number 21 on the [[UK Singles Chart]].{{cite web | title=Top 40 UK Official Singles Chart | url=http://www.theofficialcharts.com/archive-chart/_/1/2010-12-25 | publisher=[[The Official Charts Company|Official Charts]] | date=December 25, 2010 | accessdate=December 19, 2010}} ==Notes==
