revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[File:Book of Ballymote 170v.jpg|thumb|220px|fol. 170v of the Book of Ballymote, the Incipit of the ''Auraicept''.]]
'''''Auraicept na n-Éces''''' ({{IPA-ga|arakʲept na neːgʲes|}}, "the scholars' [''éices''] primer [''airaiccecht'']") is claimed as a 7th-century work of Irish [[Linguist|grammarians]], written by a scholar named '''Longarad'''. The core of the text could indeed date to the mid-7th century, but much material will have been added over the five centuries preceding the text as recorded in the earliest surviving copy (12th century).
If indeed dating to the 7th century, the text is the first instance of a defence of [[vernacular]]s, defending the spoken [[Irish language]] over [[Latin]], predating [[Dante Alighieri|Dante's]] ''[[De vulgari eloquentia]]'' by 600 years and [[Chernorizets Hrabar]]'s ''O pismeneh'' by 200 years.
==Manuscripts== # [[Trinity College, Dublin|TCD]] H 2.18. ([[Book of Leinster]]), ca. 1160 # TCD H 2.16. (YBL), 14th century #[[Royal Irish Academy|RIA]] 23 P 12 ([[Book of Ballymote]]), foll. 169r–180r, ca. 1390 #BM E.g. 88, 1564{{clarify|date=July 2012}}
==Contents== The Auraicept consists of four books, : I: The Book of [[Fenius Farsaidh]] : II: The Book of [[Amergin Glúingel|Amergin]] : III: The Book of Fercheirtne Filidh : IV: The Book of [[Cenn Fáelad mac Ailella|Cennfaeladh]]
The author argues from a comparison of Gaelic grammar with the materials used in the constructions of the [[Tower of Babel]]:
:Others affirm that in the tower there were only nine materials and that these were [[clay]] and [[water]], [[wool]] and [[blood]], [[wood]] and [[lime (material)|lime]], [[Pitch (resin)|pitch]], [[linen]], and [[bitumen]] [...] These represent noun, pronoun, verb, adverb, participle, conjunction, preposition, interjection
(note the discrepancy of nine materials vs. eight parts of speech). As pointed out by Eco (1993), Gaelic was thus argued to be the only instance of a language that overcame the [[confusion of tongues]], being the first language that was created after the fall of the tower by the seventy-two wise men of the school of [[Fenius]], choosing all that was best in each language to implement in Irish. Calder notes (p. xxxii) that the poetic list of the "72 races" was taken from a poem by [[Luccreth moccu Chiara]].
===Ogham=== The ''Auraicept'' is one of the three main sources of the manuscript tradition about [[Ogham]], the others being ''[[In Lebor Ogaim]]'' and ''[[De dúilib feda na forfed]]''. A copy of ''In Lebor Ogaim'' immediately precedes the ''Auraincept'' in the Book of Ballymote, but instead of the ''[[Bríatharogam]] Con Culainn'' given in other copies, there follows a variety of other "secret" modes of ogham. The [[Younger Futhark]] are also included, as'' ogam lochlannach'' "ogham of the Norsemen".
[[File:Book of Ballymote 170r.jpg|thumb|220px|fol. 170r of the ''Book of Ballymote'', variants of ogham, nr. 43 (''sluagogam'') to nr. 77 (''sigla'').]]
Similar to the argument of the precedence of the Gaelic language, the ''Auraicept'' claims that [[Fenius Farsa]]idh discovered four alphabets, the [[Hebrew alphabet|Hebrew]], [[Greek alphabet|Greek]] and [[Latin alphabet|Latin]] ones, and finally the [[ogham]], and that the ogham is the most perfected because it was discovered last. The text is the origin of the tradition that the ogham letters were named after trees, but it gives as an alternative possibility that the letters are named for the 25 members of Fenius' school.
In the translation of Calder (1917), :''This is their number: five Oghmic groups, i.e., five men for each group, and one up to five for each of them, that their signs may be distinguished. These are their signs: right of stem, left of stem, athwart of stem, through stem, about stem. Thus is a tree climbed, to wit, treading on the root of the tree first with thy right hand first and thy left hand after. Then with the stem, and against it and through it and about it. (Lines 947-951)''
In the translation of McManus: :''This is their number: there are five groups of ogham and each group has five letters and each of them has from one to five scores and their orientations distinguish them. Their orientations are: right of the stemline, left of the stemline, across the stemline, through the stemline, around the stemline. Ogham is climbed as a tree is climbed..."''
[[File:Fege find.png|thumb|Fege finn]]
==References== *James Acken, ''Structure and Interpretation in the Auraicept na nÉces''. Saarbrücken: [[VDM Publishing|VDM Verlag Dr. Müller e.K.]], 2008. {{ISBN|978-3-639-02030-4}} *George Calder, Auraicept na n-éces, The Scholars Primer, being the texts of the ogham tract from the Book of Ballymote and the Yellow Book of Lecan, and the text of the Trefhocul from the Book of Leinster, ... , John Grant, Edinburgh 1917 (1995 repr.) *Anders Ahlqvist, The Early Irish Linguist (Auraicept na nÉces), Helsinki 1982 * R. Thurneysen, "Auraicept na n-éces", in: ZCP 17, 1928, pp. 277–303. *Erich Poppe, "Die mittelalterliche irische Abhandlung Auraicept na nÉces und ihr geistesgeschichtlicher Standort", in: ''Theorie und Rekonstruktion'', edd. von Klaus D. Dutz & Hans-J. Niederehe. Münster: Nodus, 1996, 55-74. * Erich Poppe, "Natural and Artificial Gender in Auraicept na nÉces", in: SH 29, 1995–97, 195-203. * Erich Poppe, "Latinate Terminology in Auraicept na nÉces", in: History of Linguistics 1996. Vol. 1: Traditions in Linguistics Worldwide. Eds. David Cram, Andrew Linn, Elke Nowak. Amsterdam & Philadelphia: John Benjamins. 1999, 191-201. * Erich Poppe, "The Latin Quotations in Auraicept na nÉces: Microtexts and their Transmission", in: ''Ireland and Europe in the Early Middle Ages. Texts and Transmission'', edd. Próinséas Ní Chatháin & Michael Richter. Dublin: Four Courts. 2002, 296-312. * Umberto Eco, ''The search for the perfect language'' (1993, book translated in English 1995). * — ''Serendipities : Language and Lunacy'' (1998). * Damian McManus, ''A Guide to Ogam'', An Sagart, 1997
==Editions== *{{cite book|editor-last1=Calder|editor-first1= George|title=Auraicept na n-Éces : the scholars' primer ; being the texts of the Ogham tract from the Book of Ballymote and the Yellow Book of Lecan, and the text of the Trefhocul from the Book of Leinster|date=1995|origyear=1917|publisher=Four Courts Press|location=Blackrock|isbn=1-85182-181-3|edition=Repr. [d. Ausg.] Edinburgh 1917.|url=http://www.four-courts-press.ie/cgi/bookshow.cgi?file=a_eces.xml}}
==External links== *[https://archive.org/details/auraicept00calduoft Full text of the ''Auraicept na N-Éces'' (Calder's 1917 edition) in various formats (PDF, JP2, etc)] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051110171744/http://www.shee-eire.com/magic%26mythology/Ogham/OghamTract/ogtract.htm The Ogham Tract - ''Auraicept na N-Éces''] *[http://www.summerlands.com/crossroads/library/slideviewer/slideviewer.cgi?list=auraicept&dir=&config=&refresh=&scale=-3cycle&design=default&total=3 scan of the Ogham section] < not readable. [http://www.summerlands.com/crossroads/library/slideviewer/slideviewer.cgi?list=auraicept&dir=&config=&refresh=&width=1200&height=900.383458646617&scale=-3cycle=off&slide=1&design=default&total=3 Better resolution (server broken, 2018-03-24.)] *[http://www.equinox-project.com/ogamscales.htm The Ogam Scales from the ''Book of Ballymote''] by B. Fell
{{DEFAULTSORT:Auraicept Na N-Eces}} [[Category:7th-century books]] [[Category:Early Irish literature]] [[Category:History of linguistics]] [[Category:Irish language]] [[Category:Irish-language literature]] [[Category:Irish texts]] [[Category:Linguistics books]] [[Category:Ogham]] [[Category:Medieval literature]]

{{Infobox film | name = Battle for Sevastopol | image = Battle_of_Sevastopol_2015.jpg | caption = Russian theatrical release poster | director = [[Sergey Mokritskiy]] | producer = {{ubl|Natalia Mokritskaya|Egor Olesov}} | writer = {{ubl|Maksim Budarin|Maksim Dankevich|Leonid Korin|Egor Olesov}} | starring = {{ubl|[[Yulia Peresild]]|[[Joan Blackham]]|[[Yevgeny Tsyganov]]|Oleg Vasilkov|Vitaliy Linetskiy}} | music = Evgeniy Galperin | cinematography = Yury Korol' | editing = | distributor = [[20th Century Fox]] | released = {{Film date|2015|04|02|Russia}} | runtime = 122 minutes | country = {{ubl|Russia|Ukraine}} | language = [[Russian language|Russian]]
[[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] (dubbed)
[[English language|English]] (dubbed) }} '''''Battle for Sevastopol''''' ({{lang-ru|"Битва за Севастополь"}}; {{lang-uk|"Незламна"}} "Indestructible") is a 2015 [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[war film]] about [[Lyudmila Pavlichenko]], a young [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] who joined the [[Red Army]] to fight the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Nazi invasion of the USSR]] and became one of the deadliest [[sniper]]s in [[World War II]].[King, Gilbert (February 21, 2013). "Eleanor Roosevelt and the Soviet Sniper". Smithsonian. Retrieved 14 December 2016.] The film, a joint [[Russia|Russian]]-[[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] production, was released in both countries on April 2, 2015; its international premiere took place two weeks later at the [[Beijing International Film Festival]].[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt4084744/releaseinfo Bitva za Sevastopol (2015) - Release Info] Historically speaking, the movie revolves around the events of the [[Siege_of_Odessa_(1941)|siege of Odessa]] and the [[Siege_of_Sevastopol_(1941%E2%80%9342)|siege of Sevastopol]]. The film is directed by Sergey Mokritskiy and stars [[Yulia Peresild]] as Pavlichenko. In addition to Beijing, where Peresild was awarded Best Actress award, the film has also appeared at [[Cannes Film Festival]].[http://www.screendaily.com/festivals/cannes-news/battle-for-sevastopol-sold-into-asia/5087942.article 'Battle for Sevastopol' sold into Asia] == Plot == The film opens and closes with post-war scenes from the perspective of [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] ([[Joan Blackham]]) as she visits the protagonist Lyudmila Pavlichenko (Yulia Peresild) during the former first lady's 1957 trip to the Soviet Union. Pavlichenko's story is told through flashbacks to 1942 when Pavlichenko toured the United States with Roosevelt, and further flashbacks to Pavlichenko's experiences in the Soviet Union. After the [[Operation Barbarossa|German invasion of the USSR]], university student Pavlichenko becomes a sniper in the [[25th Rifle Division (Soviet Union)|25th Rifle Division]]. She fights in the [[Battle of Odessa (1941)|Battle of Odessa]] and, eventually, the [[Siege of Sevastopol (1941–42)|defense of Sevastopol]]. After 309 confirmed kills, she is sent to the [[United States]] to campaign for American support. Eleanor Roosevelt invites her to the White House, and the two become friends. In 1941, Lyudmila is a student who has just gotten into university; to celebrate, she goes to a shooting range with her friends including a classmate named Masha, doing exceptionally well despite never have shot before. At home, her father shows no pride in her, having desired a son who could become a soldier. In a twist of events, her perfect shooting results at the range eventually result in the military contacting her for a sharpshooting program, as Germany has just invaded the Soviet Union. Though a doctor courting her, Boris, tells her she should stay with him, she rejects what she perceives as cowardice and leaves to fight on the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]]. During training, Lyudmila is shown as an excellent sniper, and eventually is partnered with a grizzled veteran named Makarov, who she falls in love with. He doesn't return her affections, however, and explains that he had lost his wife and family when the Germans invaded. She is also reunited with Masha, who is now a nurse engaged with a young pilot. During battle defending the city of Odessa, she is injured and Makarov drags her to safety to a local hospital, where Boris has volunteered as a military doctor. After awakening, Lyudmila manages to get Boris to sign her papers so that she can return to the frontlines, but finds out that Makarov has died in battle and the Soviets are retreating to Sevastopol. She is paired with another superior, Leonid, and begins to show signs of trauma, showing signs of cruelty by shooting enemy soldiers to wound them and watch them suffer, rather than kill them instantly. Thus, their relationship starts off rough, but they eventually develop a close romance. Masha invites them to her wedding, but at the wedding reveals that her fiance had died, leaving her alone. This leads Lyudmila to tell Leonid privately that she wants a son. While on patrol in a field, Leonid steps on a mine that triggers a [[flare]]. Immediately, artillery shells begin to pummel the field, and Leonid shelters her from them with his body. Lyudmila again wakes up in a hospital, where Boris tells her Leonid has died. Though in a broken state, she is ordered to kill a top enemy sniper for propaganda purposes. The duel takes all of a day, and, tired of waiting, Lyudmila steps out of cover, exposing herself completely. She is shot, but manages to pinpoint the enemy sniper's location and kills him. Boris eventually is able to pull her away from battle. As the city is being evacuated, Boris carries a traumatized Lyudmila to a submarine that is evacuating the city. As panicked civilians attempt to board evacuating ships, Lyudmila realizes that Boris isn't coming with her, as he gave her his ticket. A voiceover by Eleanor Roosevelt reveals that Boris, Masha, and countless civilians and soldiers died defending the city from the Germans. Roosevelt later visits Lyudmila after the war, where she is now a mother. They attend the opera together, with Lyudmila's son. == Production == The filming began in 2012 after the first archive material devoted to Pavlichenko was examined. Serhiy Mokrytskyi, who is better known as a cinematographer, served as director; after his arrival, the plot was altered to more closely match Pavlichenko's life. During production, there was concern of the growing [[Russia-Ukraine relations|political tension between Russia and Ukraine]]. However, the film was successfully released in both countries on the same day, in each country's own respective language. ==Box office== The movie grossed [[Ruble|RUB]] 435,468,256 ($8,702,274) in the Russian box office against a budget of RUB 124,000,000 and hence was a commercial success.https://www.kinopoisk.ru/film/742026/ == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|4084744|Battle for Sevastopol}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|bitva_za_sevastopol}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nR7Wdy-3-TA Official trailer], via the official YouTube channel of 20th Century Fox Russia [[Category:2015 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s war films]] [[Category:Eastern Front of World War II films]] [[Category:Biographical films about military personnel]] [[Category:War drama films]] [[Category:Ukrainian films]] [[Category:Russian films]] [[Category:Russian war films]] [[Category:Films set in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Films set in 1941]] [[Category:Films set in 1942]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Eleanor Roosevelt]]

{{Infobox film | name = Bitter Honey | genre = Documentary Film | image = | caption = | director = [[Robert Lemelson]] | producer = Robert Lemelson
Alessandra Pasquino | cinematography = Wing Ko | editing = Chisako Yokoyama | music = Malcolm Cross | studio = Elemental Productions | released = {{Film date|2014|10|03|United States}} | runtime = 82 minutes | country = United States | language = Indonesian
Balinese
English}} '''''Bitter Honey''''' is a 2014 [[documentary film]] directed by anthropologist and filmmaker [[Robert Lemelson]] that chronicles the lives of three polygamous families living in [[Bali|Bali, Indonesia]]. The film follows the wives from their introduction to the polygamous lifestyle to the emotional hardships and jealousies to their struggle for empowerment and equal rights. ==Production== ''Bitter Honey'' was directed by Robert Lemelson, an anthropologist and filmmaker with a doctorate from [[UCLA]].https://www.imdb.com/name/nm3199649/ Lemelson had originally been researching the [[May 1998 riots of Indonesia|1998 mass rapes]] perpetrated during the economic crisis and the fall of the [[Suharto]] regime. Realizing that these acts were only one piece of the larger puzzle of gender inequality in Indonesia, Lemelson shifted his focus to domestic violence and particularly how it coincided with polygamous kinship forms.{{cite news | url=http://theblot.com/bitter-honey-shows-ugly-side-of-bali-where-polygamy-and-domestic-abuse-reign-7726463 | title= ‘Bitter Honey' shows ugly side of Bali, where polygamy and domestic abuse reign | work=[[The Blot]] | date=October 2, 2014 | accessdate=January 14, 2015 | author=Olds, Dorri}}{{cite news | url=http://newsroom.ucla.edu/stories/anthropologist-s-film-exposes-plight-of-polygamy-in-indonesia | title= Anthropologist’s film exposes plight of polygamy in Indonesia | work=[[UCLA Newsroom]] | date=September 25, 2014 | accessdate=January 14, 2015 | author=Barrosse, Emilia}} The film’s title refers to a regional play on words, as the local term for co-wife (''madu'') also translates to “honey.”{{cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/31/movies/bitter-honey-looks-at-multiple-spouses-in-bali.html?_r=4 | title= The Pain of Polygamy | work=[[New York Times]] | date=October 30, 2014 | accessdate=January 14, 2015 | author=Webster, Andy}} The film was shot over a period of seven years.{{cite news | url=http://www.leveledmag.com/2014/10/bitter-honey-documentary-polygamy-violence/ | title= Bitter Honey: A Documentary on Polygamy, Love and Violence | work=[[Leveled Magazine]] |date=October 1, 2014 | accessdate= January 14, 2015 | author=Maleszka, Jamie}} Lemelson used this longitudinal approach to gain the trust of his subjects, saying, “We returned over and over so that people could see we weren’t just there to get data and never return.” The film is presented in thematic chapters, with each new section introduced by a traditional [[Wayang | Wayang Kulit]] shadow-puppet performance about the issues surrounding polygamous unions. The filmmakers commissioned this performance for use in the film.{{cite news | url=https://variety.com/2014/film/reviews/film-review-bitter-honey-1201321492/ | title=Film Review: ‘Bitter Honey’ | work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=October 4, 2014 | accessdate=January 14, 2015 | author=Harvey, Dennis}} In earlier cuts of “Bitter Honey”, the film had focused on the husbands in these polygamous arrangements, but Lemelson quickly realized that the more compelling story arose from examining how these marriages are experienced by the co-wives. ==Synopsis== The film follows the lives of three polygamous families living in Bali, Indonesia, where [[polygyny|polygynous]] unions make up about 10% of households.{{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-bitter-honey-movie-review-20141003-story.html | title=‘Bitter Honey’ doesn’t sugarcoat polygamy | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=October 2, 2014 | accessdate=January 14, 2015 | author=Linden, Sheri}} The first is the family of Sadra, a fair trade craftsman with two wives and eight children living in separate compounds. Sadra’s main narrative thread concerns generational cycles of violence and his abusive relationship with his first wife and mother, and its effect on his children. At one point in the narrative, Sadra’s first wife requests the help of his boss and a local human rights lawyer to stage an intervention confronting Sadra about his abusive behavior. The second family is that of local thug and cockfight organizer, Darma. His five wives each describe how they were “tricked or badgered” into accepting a polygamous marriage and their efforts to come to terms with it.{{cite news | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/bitter-honey-film-review-729282 | title=‘Bitter Honey’: Film Review | work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=September 15, 2014 | accessdate=January 14, 2015 | author=DeFore, John}} Darma frequently seeks sexual relationships outside of his marital bonds, including with sex workers—putting himself and his wives at risk of STD infection.{{cite news | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/bitter-honey-movie-review/2014/11/05/e83fb7e2-5fb1-11e4-8b9e-2ccdac31a031_story.html | title=‘Bitter Honey’ movie review | work=[[The Washington Post]] | date=November 6, 2014 | accessdate=January 14, 2015 | author=Merry, Stephanie }} Consisting of ten wives, the third family profiled is that of Sang Putu Tuaji, a powerful elderly man who was the leader of a local anti-communist militia. ==Release== The film opened in limited theatrical release in the United States on October 3, 2014.http://www.bitterhoneyfilm.com/screenings/ ==Critical response== Critical reception was mixed to positive, with reviewers praising the film for its objective illumination of cultural issues in relation to gender status in Indonesia.{{cite news | url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/movies/2014/10/23/movie-review-bitter-honey-leaves-unsettling-taste/1BuXQwM4K9migdN9NzTv7M/story.html | title=‘Bitter Honey’ leaves an unsettling taste | work=[[The Boston Globe]] | date=October 23, 2014 | accessdate=January 14, 2015 | author=Keough, Peter}} Many reviewers praised the film for its potential as an educational tool within Bali as well as in Western classrooms. Critics of the film believed it to be too narrow in its focus. Dennis Harvey of [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] wrote, “Intriguing enough in what it shows, ''Bitter Honey'' nonetheless frustrates for what it doesn’t.” The review aggregator website [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reported an overall 67% positive approval rating based on 9 reviews, and a [[Weighted mean|rating average]] of 5.8 out of 10.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/bitter_honey/|title= Bitter Honey (2014)|work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|date= |accessdate=January 15, 2014|publisher=Flixter, Inc.}} On [[Metacritic]], the film has an average score of 62 out of 100, based on 6 reviews, indicating “generally favorable reviews.”{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/bitter-honey|title=Bitter Honey|website=Metacritic}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://bitterhoneyfilm.com/}} *[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt3383158/?ref_=nm_knf_t4 ''Bitter Honey'' at IMDB] [[Category:2014 films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:Visual anthropology]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Ethnography]] [[Category:Anthropology documentary films]] [[Category:Films shot in Indonesia]] [[Category:Indonesian-language films]] [[Category:Documentary films about women]] [[Category:Documentary films about Indonesia]] [[Category:Films about polygamy]] [[Category:Films directed by Robert Lemelson]]

revision.comment: Add section about acquisition by Jacobs ~~~~
revision.text:
{{advert|date=February 2017}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = CH2M HILL Companies Ltd. | logo = Ch2m logo.png | logo_size = 250px | type = [[Subsidiary]] | foundation = [[Corvallis, Oregon]] (1946)
(as Cornell, Howland, Hayes, and Merryfield) | location = [[Meridian, Colorado]], United States | key_people = [[Jacqueline Hinman]], president and chief executive officer{{cite web|title=Jacqueline Hinman,|deadurl=yes|url=http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/bios/jacqueline-hinman|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202093752/http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/bios/jacqueline-hinman|archivedate=February 2, 2014|df=mdy-all}} | num_employees = 26,000 (2013){{cite web | url =http://pdf.secdatabase.com/671/0001047469-14-001244.pdf | title = CH2M Hill Companies Ltd 2013 Annual Report – Form 10-K – February 25, 2014. | publisher = secdatabase.com | accessdate = 2014-07-30}} | parent = [[Jacobs Engineering Group]] | revenue = {{decrease}}US$5.88 Billion (''FY 2013'') | operating_income = {{profit}}US$192.4M (''FY 2013'') | net_income = {{profit}}US$118.3M (''FY 2013'') | assets = {{decrease}}US$3.06 Billion (''FY 2013'') | equity = {{increase}}US$642.6M (''FY 2013'') | industry = Engineering, procurement, construction, and operations }} '''CH2M HILL''', also known as '''CH2M''', was a global engineering company that provided consulting, design, construction, and operations services for corporations, and federal, state, and local governments. The firm's headquarters was in [[Meridian, Colorado|Meridian]], an unincorporated area of [[Douglas County, Colorado]], in the [[Denver-Aurora Metropolitan Area]]. The postal designation of nearby [[Englewood, Colorado|Englewood]] was commonly listed as the company's location in corporate filings and local news accounts. As of December 2013, CH2M had approximately 26,000 employees and 2013 revenues totaled $5.88 billion. The firm was [[employee-owned company|employee owned]],{{cite web|url=http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/about_us/employee_ownership/default.asp|publisher=CH2M Hill|title=Employee Ownership|accessdate=2007-09-04|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070831165324/http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/about_us/employee_ownership/default.asp|archivedate=August 31, 2007|df=mdy-all}} with an internal stock market that operated buy/sell events quarterly. CH2M HILL announced a global rebrand on 13 April 2015, adopting the nickname '''CH2M''' while retaining CH2M HILL Companies Ltd. as the firm's legal name.{{cite web|url=http://www.ch2m.com/newsroom/news/ch2m-announces-first-global-rebrand-in-two-decades|title=CH2M Announces First Global Rebrand in Two Decades; Aligns Strategy and Focus with Clients' Ch2m about to be bought by Jacobs too. Neels|last=|first=|date=|website=CH2M|publisher=CH2M|accessdate=20 April 2015}} In December 2017, it was announced that CH2M had been acquired by Jacobs Engineering Group, a Dallas Engineering firm, reportedly for $3.3 Billion. {{cite web|url=https://www.denverpost.com/2017/12/18/ch2m-colorado-jacobs-engineering-group-purchase/ |title=CH2M, one of Colorado’s largest private companies, is swallowed up by Texas firm}} ==History== CH2M was founded in 1946 in [[Corvallis, Oregon]], by [[Oregon State University]] civil engineering professor Fred Merryfield and three of his students: Holly Cornell, James Howland and Thomas Burke Hayes (the firm was named after the founders, with Howland and Hayes making up the '''H2''' portion).{{cite web|url=http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/about_us/history.asp |title=CH2M Hill – Our History |publisher=Ch2m.com |accessdate=October 18, 2011}} Cornell, Howland, and Hayes were all graduates of Oregon State University.{{cite web|url=http://oregonstate.edu/ |title=Oregon State University |publisher=Oregonstate.edu |accessdate=October 18, 2011}} The company became CH2M Hill, after a merger in 1971 with Clair A. Hill and Associates of [[Redding, California]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/about_us/history.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-10-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402214509/http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/about_us/history.asp |archivedate=April 2, 2015 |df=mdy }}, CH2M.com The firm remained headquartered in Oregon until 1980, when a decision was made to relocate to Colorado, a more central location in the United States. On August 2, 2017, CH2M agreed to be purchased by [[Jacobs Engineering Group Inc.]] in a US$2.85 billion cash and stock deal. Shareholders approved the deal in December 2017,{{cite news|title=CH2M shareholders back merger with Jacobs|url=http://www.theconstructionindex.com/news/view/ch2m-shareholders-back-merger-with-jacobs|accessdate=18 December 2017|work=The Construction Index|date=15 December 2017}} and the completion of the acquisition was announced on 18 December.{{cite news|title=Jacobs completes acquisition of CH2M|url=http://www.theconstructionindex.co.uk/news/view/jacobs-completes-acquisition-of-ch2m|accessdate=18 December 2017|work=The Construction Index|date=18 December 2017}} ==Services== [[File:Slc parkside tower.jpg|thumb|CH2M Hill offices at the Parkside Tower in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]]] [[File:CH2anchorage.JPG|thumb|right|The former VECO building, now CH2M Hill's Alaska headquarters]] The company operates in multiple business units,{{cite web |url=http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/ |title=CH2M Hill – Home |publisher=Ch2m.com |accessdate=October 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018083359/http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/ |archivedate=October 18, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} among the operating divisions, Water, Energy & Facilities; Government, Environment & Infrastructure; and International. Business groups served include: Water; Transportation; Operations and Maintenance; Government Facilities and Infrastructure; Nuclear; Environmental; Energy and Chemicals; Power; and Industrial and Advanced Technology. The company developed, maintains and publishes its own method for managing projects for clients, called the CH2M Hill Project Delivery System, which may be found at popular internet book retailers.{{cite book |url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/project-delivery-a-system-and-process-for-benchmark-performance/oclc/668106433&referer=brief_results|title=Project Delivery System : A System and Process for Benchmark Performance|author=CH2M Hill Project Managers|publisher=CH2M Hill {{hyphen}} Denver, CO|year=2000|oclc=668106433|isbn=0965261603|access-date=March 31, 2018}} As a firm specializing in project management, CH2M Hill has been associated in several large, complex projects around the world. In 2005, a CH2M Hill joint venture known as Kaiser Hill decommissioned and closed a former nuclear weapons facility at the Rocky Flats site in Colorado [[Rocky Flats Plant|(former Rocky Flats Plant)]]. In [[Singapore]], the company was part of a joint venture to replace the country's sanitary services infrastructure.{{cite news| url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0EIN/is_2000_Feb_21/ai_59580733 | work=Business Wire | title=CH2M Hill and PWD Consultants Awarded $123.9 Million Contract for Portion of One of the World's Largest Wastewater Projects | date=February 21, 2000}} The new Singapore Deep Tunnel System was designed to improve reliability, ease, and economy of operation, and to help handle Singapore's increasing waterfront utilization.{{cite web|last=Rowson |first=Jessica |url=http://www.nce.co.uk/news/water/singapore-sewerage-no-space-to-waste/5203685.article |title=Singapore sewerage: No space to waste | Features | New Civil Engineer |publisher=Nce.co.uk |date=June 17, 2009 |accessdate=October 18, 2011}} CH2M Hill assisted in reconstruction efforts along the [[Gulf Coast of the United States|US Gulf Coast]] in the wake of [[Hurricane Katrina]].{{cite web|url=http://www.taxpayer.net/budget/katrinaspending/contracts/ch2mhill.htm |title=Federal Budget and Tax Policy {{hyphen}} CH2M Hill|website=www.taxpayer.net|date=December 21, 2005|accessdate=March 31, 2018 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061130060945/http://www.taxpayer.net/budget/katrinaspending/contracts/ch2mhill.htm |archivedate=November 30, 2006 }} Its main assignments included providing temporary housing, debris removal, and other services. Other large projects include a $660 million gas fired power plant in Australia, in conjunction with General Electric,{{cite web|url=http://www.oilvoice.com/GE_Energy_CH2M_Hill_To_Build_Coal_Seam_GasFired_Power_Plant_/9875.htm |title=GE Energy, CH2M Hill To Build Coal Seam Gas-Fired Power Plant In Australia |date=June 14, 2007|publisher=Keyfacts|website=www.oilvoice.com|accessdate=March 31, 2018 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927185010/http://www.oilvoice.com/GE_Energy_CH2M_Hill_To_Build_Coal_Seam_GasFired_Power_Plant_/9875.htm |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }} and an $11.7 billion project to relocate American military bases in Korea.{{cite web|url=http://www.dynamic-korea.com/news/view_news.php?main=KTD&sub=&uid=200700169044&keyword= |title=Dynamic-Korea |publisher=Dynamic-Korea |date=June 10, 2007 |accessdate=October 18, 2011}} In August 2007, the [[Panama Canal Authority]] selected CH2M Hill to manage the $5.25 billion [[Panama Canal expansion project]], which will add new locks to the Pacific and Atlantic ends of the canal and allow [[Panamax|Post Panamax]] ships passage through the canal for the first time.{{cite web |url=https://www.canadianconsultingengineer.com/engineering/ch2m-hill-lands-panama-canal-expansion-contract/1000068480/ |title=CH2M Hill lands Panama Canal expansion contract |date=August 7, 2007 |publisher=Annex Business Media |website=www.canadianconsultingengineer.com |access-date=March 31, 2018}}{{cite web |url=https://www.enr.com/articles/30896-ch2m-hill-selected-as-5-billion-panama-canal-expansion-program-manager?v=preview |title=CH2M Hill Selected as $5-billion Panama Canal Expansion Program Manager|date=August 17, 2007 |publisher=BNP Media |website=www.enr.com |subscription=yes|access-date=March 31, 2018}}{{closed access}} In 2009, a CH2M Hill consortium was named program partner to oversee construction of the [[Crossrail]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2009/03/30/daily44.html |title=CH2M Hill, partners to oversee $22B 'Crossrail' project in London|date=Apr 1, 2009|website=www.bizjournals.com|publisher=American City Business Journals|accessdate=March 31, 2018 }} project to expand London's transit system. On August 30, 2006, as part of joint venture CLM, CH2M Hill was a supplier for the [[London 2012 Olympics]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aroundtherings.com/article.php?pid=2646 |title=Press Release: London Olympics Delivery Partner |publisher=Around the Rings|website=www.aroundtherings.com|accessdate=March 31, 2018 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021065221/http://www.aroundtherings.com/article.php?pid=2646 |archivedate=October 21, 2006}} The other two members of the venture are project management service provider [[Mace (construction company)|Mace Group]] and [[Laing O'Rourke]], the largest privately owned construction firm in the United Kingdom. The company manages projects for the clients, taking into account the [[environmental footprint]], aiming to use sustainable technology. The firm reduced its own internal environmental footprint in 2011.{{cite web |url=http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/pr/ch2m/leader-in-sustainable-engineering-193466.aspx |title=Leader in Sustainable Engineering Improves Internal Environmental Performance for Sixth Year / CH2M HIll |publisher=Newsroom.ch2mhill.com |date=March 8, 2011 |accessdate=October 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110823060533/http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/pr/ch2m/leader-in-sustainable-engineering-193466.aspx |archivedate=August 23, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} In 2008, the [[U.S. Department of Energy]] (DOE) contracted a CH2M Hill company, CH2M Hill Plateau Remediation Company, LLC (CHPRC), to manage deconstruction and remediation of the Central Plateau on the Hanford Nuclear Site in eastern Washington, one of the world's largest environmental cleanup projects. The project focused on shrinking the environmental footprint of the Hanford Site from a {{convert|586|sqmi|km2|adj=on}} area (large enough to fit the city of Los Angeles) to {{convert|75|sqmi|km2}} or less. More importantly, the project will reduce legacy infrastructure costs on site by more than $25 million per year starting in 2015. Using [[American Recovery and Reinvestment Act]] (ARRA) funding, CHPRC sped up cleanup of the site over two years, reducing the site footprint 25 percent, employing an additional 1,350 people in the process.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} When ARRA funded work concludes in September 2012, the site footprint was targeted to shrink to a total of {{convert|290|sqmi|km2}}, roughly half its previous size. Without ARRA funding, however, the scope of DOE contracted work at Hanford will be reduced. The company also announced that its workforce would reduce by up to 1,350 workers later that year through a combination of voluntary and involuntary separations.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} In February 2012, the Qatar 2022 Supreme Committee appointed the company to manage the delivery of the [[2022 FIFA World Cup]] in [[Qatar]].[http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/pr/ch2m/ch2m-hill-is-qatar-22-consultant-228676.aspx Qatar Supreme Committee Appoints CH2M Hill as the Programme Management Consultant for 2022 FIFA World Cup™ / CH2M Hill] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414080133/http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/pr/ch2m/ch2m-hill-is-qatar-22-consultant-228676.aspx |date=April 14, 2012 }}. Newsroom.ch2mhill.com (February 8, 2012). CH2M HILL are the developers of [[Flood Modeller Pro]], an industry leading flood risk modelling and real time [[flood forecasting]] suite of software. ==Acquisitions== Key acquisitions include Black, Crow & Eidsness (a southeast engineering firm in the United States) in 1977,{{cite news|title=CH2M Hill Acquires Black, Crow & Eidsness, Inc|url=http://www.environmental-expert.com/articles/news-of-the-field-ch2m-hill-acquires-black-crow-eidsness-inc-63851|accessdate=20 April 2015|work=Environmental Expert|date=1 January 1977}} Gore & Storrie (a Canadian water and wastewater engineering firm) in 1995, {{cite web | url = http://www.alumni.ch2m.com/History/reward.htm | title = The History of CH2M Hill: Part VI - The Reward Years, 1990{{hyphen}}2000 | website = www.alumni.ch2m.com | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20050217030453/http://www.alumni.ch2m.com/History/reward.htm | archivedate = February 16, 2005 | accessdate = April 1, 2018 }} Gee & Jensen (a Ports and Harbor firm based in Florida) in August 2002,{{cite web|url=http://www.secinfo.com/dVut2.z4ch.htm |title=CH2M Hill Companies Ltd – 10-K – For 12/31/04 |publisher=SEC Info |accessdate=October 18, 2011}} DeMil International (a weapons destruction firm based in the United States) in 2002,{{cite news| url=http://www.bizjournals.com/denver/stories/2002/08/19/daily47.html | title=CH2M Hill buys blast chamber company, technology | date=August 23, 2002}} EHS Consultants Ltd (a consulting firm based in Hong Kong), {{cite web | url = https://www.cbr.ca/CompanyProfile.aspx?CompanyID=24520 | title = Corporate Profile: CH2M Hill | publisher = Canadian Newspaper Services International Limited | website = www.cbr.ca | author = Canadian Business Resource | accessdate = April 1, 2018 }} [[J.A. Jones Construction#Sell-off|Lockwood Greene]], the oldest continuously operating professional services firm in the United States in December 2003,{{cite web |url=http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/clients/lg.asp |title=CH2M Hill Lockwood Greene |publisher=Ch2m.com |accessdate=October 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928154244/http://www.ch2m.com/corporate/clients/lg.asp |archivedate=September 28, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} and BBS Corporation (an environmental engineering firm based in Ohio) in October 2005.{{cite web |author=Brian E. Sturtevant |url=http://www.caprep.com/b1005001.htm |title=BBS Corporation Joins CH2M Hill |publisher=Caprep.com |accessdate=October 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001000831/http://www.caprep.com/b1005001.htm |archivedate=October 1, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} On September 7, 2007, CH2M HILL finalized the purchase of most of the components of [[VECO]], an Alaska based firm specialising in services to the oil, gas, and energy sector that had become embroiled in the [[Alaska political corruption probe]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/cgi-bin/stories.pl?ACCT=109&STORY=/www/story/09-07-2007/0004658708&EDATE= |title=CH2M Hill Finalizes Acquisition of VECO – re> DENVER, Sept. 7 /PRNewswire/ |publisher=Prnewswire.com |accessdate=October 18, 2011}} In December 2007, CH2M Hill acquired Trigon EPC.{{cite web|url=http://www.rockymountainnews.com/news/2008/jan/17/ch2m-hill-raises-energy-level/ |title=CH2M Hill raises energy level : Energy |publisher=The Rocky Mountain News |date=January 17, 2008 |accessdate=October 18, 2011}} In March 2008, CH2M Hill acquired Texas based Goldston Engineering, a company specialising in marine and coastal transportation engineering services. {{cite web | url = http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/Ch2M-Hill-829174.html | title = CH2M Hill Press Release: CH2M HILL Finalizes Acquisition of Texas-Based Goldston Engineering | publisher = Marketwired L.P. | website = www.marketwire.com | author = CH2M Hill | archive-url = http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160520053945/http://www.marketwire.com/press-release/Ch2M-Hill-829174.html | dead-url = yes | archive-date = May 20, 2016 | accessdate = July 24, 2009 }} In July 2011, CH2M Hill finalised the acquisition of [[Booz Allen Hamilton]]'s State & Local Government Transportation Consulting (S&L Transportation) business. In September 2011, CH2M Hill announced that it intended to acquire the share capital of [[Halcrow Group Limited]], a engineering consultancy based in the United Kingdom that operates worldwide.{{cite web |url=http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/pr/ch2m/ch2m-hill-announces-intent-to-216162.aspx |title=CH2M Hill Announces Intent to Acquire Halcrow / CH2M Hill |publisher=Newsroom.ch2mhill.com |date=September 26, 2011 |accessdate=October 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930072350/http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/pr/ch2m/ch2m-hill-announces-intent-to-216162.aspx |archivedate=September 30, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} The acquisition for £124m was completed on November 10, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/pr/ch2m/completion-of-acquisition-of-halcrow-218791.aspx |title=Completion of Acquisition of Halcrow / CH2M Hill |publisher=Newsroom.ch2mhill.com |date=November 10, 2011 |accessdate=November 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111111201908/http://newsroom.ch2mhill.com/pr/ch2m/completion-of-acquisition-of-halcrow-218791.aspx |archivedate=November 11, 2011 |df= }} In 2014, CH2M Hill acquired TERA Environmental Consultants of Calgary, Alberta. ==Acquisition by Jacobs Engineering== In December 2017, Jacobs Engineering announced that it had acquired CH2M. The acquisition was supported by 96% of CH2M employee shareholders. {{cite web|url=http://invest.jacobs.com/investors/Press-Release-Details/2017/Jacobs-Completes-CH2M-Acquisition-Creating-15-Billion-Professional-Services-Leader-Focused-on-Delivering-Innovative-Solutions-for-a-More-Connected-Sustainable-World/default.aspx |title=Jacobs Completes CH2M Acquisition }} ==See also== * [[Top 100 US Federal Contractors]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=25em}} ==External links== * [http://scarc.library.oregonstate.edu/oh150/matthews/index.html LaMont Matthews Oral History Interview] {{Petroleum industry}} {{DEFAULTSORT:CH2M Hill}} [[Category:Engineering companies of the United States]] [[Category:Engineering consulting firms]] [[Category:Companies based in Oregon]] [[Category:Corvallis, Oregon]] [[Category:Companies based in Meridian, Colorado]] [[Category:American companies established in 1946]] [[Category:Construction and civil engineering companies established in 1946]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1946]] [[Category:1946 establishments in Oregon]] [[Category:2017 mergers and acquisitions]]

revision.comment: [[:en:WP:CLEANER|WPCleaner]] v1.35 - Repaired 1 link to disambiguation page - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[John Giffard]]
revision.text:
The '''Camden Roll''' is a 13th-century English [[roll of arms]] believed to have been created c. 1280, containing 270 painted [[coats of arms]] with 185 French [[blazon]]s for various English and European monarchs, lords and knights.
The original roll is now held at the [[British Museum]] as Cotton Roll XV. 8. It consists of three [[vellum]] membranes in total measuring 6.25" by 63". The face of the roll consists of 270 painted shields arranged in 45 rows of six shields, each with associated names and/or titles listed above each shield. The dorse includes French blazons for 185 of the shields on the face.<ref name="Aspilogia I">{{cite book|last=Wagner|first=Anthony Richard|title=A Catalogue of English Medieval Rolls of Arms.|year=1950|publisher=Charles Batey for The Society of Antiquaries|location=Society Of Antiquaries|isbn=0854312129|pages=16–17}}</ref>
==Provenance== The roll belonged to [[William Camden]], [[Clarenceux King of Arms]], c. 1605, and is believed to have been among several documents and manuscripts which were willed to [[Sir Robert Cotton, 1st Baronet, of Connington]], in 1623. In 1700 Sir John Cotton, Sir Robert's grandson, sold the [[Cotton library|Cottonian library]] to the nation, and in 1753 the collection was granted to the British Museum in London.<ref name="Aspilogia I" />
==Contents== The coats on the face of the roll are loosely divided into the following sections:<ref name="Aspilogia I" /> *Shields 1-18: Emperors and kings *Shields 19-24: Foreign dukes *Shields 25, 27, 29, 30, 34, 36, 37: English earls *Shield 26: "Sire Aunfour" ([[Alphonso, Earl of Chester|Alphonso of England, Earl of Chester]], eldest son of [[Edward I of England|Edward I]]) *Shield 28: "Prince of Gales" ([[Edward II of England|Prince of Wales]]) *Shields 31-3, and 35: Foreign counts *The rest are those of English lords and knights, with the following exceptions: 44-51, 54, 56-61, 71-2, 83, 88, 94, 102, 181, 184, 207-8, 226, 240, 243, 246, 256-67, 270 The blazons, written in French on the dorse, are of the shields 1-202 with the omission of 9 "Rey de Escoce" ([[King of Scotland]]), 86 "Johan Giffard" ([[John Giffard (died 1299)|John Giffard]]), and several others.
==Copies== ''16th Century'' *A. Held at [[The Queen's College, Oxford]], MS. 158, pp. 349–65. Tricked by [[Robert Glover (officer of arms)|Robert Glover, Somerset Herald of Arms]]. *B. Held at the [[College of Arms]], MS. Vincent 164, ff. 111-19. Trick believed to be attributed to Richard Scarlett. *C. Held at the [[British Museum]], MS. Harl. 6137, ff. 66b-72b. Tricked by Richard Kimbey. ''17th Century'' *D. Held at the College of Arms, MS. L. 14, ff. 62-70. Trick is attributed to [[Nicholas Charles]], [[Lancaster Herald|Lancaster Herald of Arms]].
==Modern Illustrations== Illustrated by [https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/User:Rs-nourse R. S. Nourse] based on the list of blazons in James Greenstreet's "The Original Camden Roll of Arms" published in Vol. XXXVIII of ''The Journal of the British Archaeological Society'', 1882.<ref name=JOBAS>{{cite journal|last=Greenstreet|first=James|title=The Original Camden Roll of Arms|journal=Journal of the British Archaeological Society|year=1882|volume=XXXVIII|pages=309–28}}</ref> <gallery> File:CAMDEN ROLL - Panel 1 - shields 1 to 54.jpg|PANEL 1 - shields 1 to 54 File:CAMDEN ROLL - Panel 2 - shields 55 to 108.jpg|PANEL 2 - shields 55 to 108 File:CAMDEN ROLL - Panel 3 - shields 109 to 162.jpg|PANEL 3 - shields 109 to 162 File:CAMDEN ROLL - Panel 4 - shields 163 to 216.jpg|PANEL 4 - shields 163 to 216 File:CAMDEN ROLL - Panel 5 - shields 217 to 270.jpg|PANEL 5 - shields 217 to 270 </gallery>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Armorials]] [[Category:Illuminated heraldic manuscripts]] [[Category:Cotton Library]] [[Category:13th-century historical documents]] [[Category:1280s works]]

{{refimprove|date=December 2009}} In [[drama]], particularly the [[tragedies]] of [[classical antiquity]], the '''catastrophe''' is the final resolution in a poem or narrative plot, which unravels the intrigue and brings the piece to a close. In comedies, this may be a marriage between [[main character]]s; in tragedies, it may be the death of one or more main characters. It is the final part of a play, following the [[protasis]], [[epitasis]], and [[catastasis]].
The catastrophe is either simple or complex, for which also the [[fable]] and action are denominated. In a simple catastrophe, there is no change in the state of the main characters, nor any discovery or unravelling; the plot being only a mere passage out of agitation, to quiet and repose. This catastrophe is rather accommodated to the nature of the [[Epic poetry|epic]] poem, than of the tragedy.<ref name="cyclo">{{1728}}</ref>
In a complex catastrophe, the main character undergoes a change of fortune, sometimes by means of a discovery, and sometimes without. The qualifications of this change are that it be probable and necessary: in order to be probable, it must be the natural result or effect of the foregoing actions, ''i.e.'' it must spring from the subject itself, or take its rise from the incidents, and not be introduced merely to serve a turn.<ref name="cyclo"/>
The ''discovery'' in a complex catastrophe must have the same qualifications as the catastrophe itself, of which it is a principal part: it must be both probable and necessary. To be probable, it must spring out of the subject itself; not affected by means of marks or tokens, rings, bracelets, or by a mere recollection, as is frequently done both in ancient and modern times. To be necessary, it must never leave the characters it concerns in the same sentiments they had before, but still produce either love or hatred, etc. Sometimes, the change consists in the discovery, sometimes it follows at a distance, and sometimes results immediately from it; the last was used, for example, in ''[[Oedipus Rex]]''.<ref name="cyclo"/>
Among critics, it has long been debated whether the catastrophe should always end happily, and favorably on the side of virtue, or not; ''i.e.'' whether virtue is always to be rewarded, and vice punished, in the catastrophe. [[Aristotle]], for example, preferred a shocking catastrophe, rather than a happy one; in that regard, the moving of terror and pity, which is the aim of tragedy, is better effected by the former than the latter.<ref name="cyclo"/>
[[René Le Bossu]], a 17th-century French critic, divides the catastrophe, at least with regards to epics, into the unravelling, or ''[[denouement]]'', and the finishing, or ''achievement''; the latter of which he makes the result of the former, and to consist in the hero's passage out of a state of trouble and agitation, to rest and quiet. This period is but a point, without extent or duration; in which it differs from the former, which comprehends everything after the plot is laid. He adds, that there are several unravellings in a piece, each interconnected. The ''finishing'' is the end of the last unravelling.<ref name="cyclo"/>
In the twentieth century, [[John Ronald Reuel Tolkien|J.R.R. Tolkien]] distinguished between what he called the ''catastrophe'' and the ''[[eucatastrophe]]''. The eucatastrophe is a classical catastrophe with an unexpected positive outcome for the protagonist. This term was coined to distance itself from the vernacular use of the word 'catastrophe' to signify disaster (which gave the term negative connotations in everyday usage).
==See also== *[[Denouement]] *[[Dramatic_structure|Dramatic Structure]]
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Ancient Greek theatre]] [[Category:Drama]]

page.title: Catharine E. B. Cox Award for Excellence in the Visual Arts

revision.text:
The '''Catharine E. B. Cox Award for Excellence in the Visual Arts''' is a biannual award given to a visual artist who is a former or current resideni of [[Hawaii]].<ref>Wong, Allison, Catharine E. B. Cox Award Exhibition, ''Honolulu Museum of Art'', Dec.-Feb. 2012/13, p. 6</ref> The recipient may work in any medium, and is honored with a solo exhibition at the [[Honolulu Museum of Art]]. The award was established in 1985 by Charles S. Cox of [[La Jolla, California]], Doak C. Cox of [[Honolulu]] and Richard H. Cox of Honolulu to honor their grandmother, [[Catharine Elizabeth Bean Cox]].
Recipients of the award have been: * 1990 [[Dorothy Faison]] * 1992 [[Michael Tom]] * 1994 [[Laura Smith (artist)|Laura Smith]] * 1996 [[Shigeru Miyamoto (artist)|Shigeru Miyamoto]] * 1998 [[Hanae Uechi Mills]] * 2000 [[Renee Iijima]] * 2002 [[Yida Wang]] * 2004 [[Lonny Tomono]] * 2006 [[Kaili Chun|Ka'ili Chun]] * 2008 [[Leland Miyano]] * 2010 [[Sanit Khewhok]]<ref>{{cite news |title= Island renaissance artist Khewhok wins Cox Award |author= Victoria Gail-White |newspaper= ''[[Honolulu Advertiser]]'' |date= January 10, 2010 |url= http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2010/Jan/10/il/hawaii1100317.html |accessdate= November 17, 2010 }}</ref> * 2012 [[John Tanji Koga]]<ref>Wong, Allison, Catharine E. B. Cox Award Exhibition, ''Honolulu Museum of Art'', Dec.-Feb. 2012/13, p. 6</ref> * 2015 [[Maya Lea Portner]]<ref>Jensen, James, Maya Lea Portner: Urbanophilia/Urbanophobia‒Love and Fear of the City, ''Honolulu Museum of Art'', June-Aug. 2015, p. 10</ref> * 2017 [[Charles Cohan]]<ref>Johnston, Healoha, "Ground: New Works by Charles Cohan", ''Honolulu Museum of Art'', Sept•Oct•Nov 2017, p. 9</ref>
Also see: * [[Catharine Elizabeth Bean Cox]]
==Footnotes== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''DFMA''' stands for Design for Manufacture and Assembly. DFMA is the combination of two methodologies; [[Design for manufacturability|Design for Manufacture]], which means the design for ease of manufacture of the parts that will form a product, and [[Design for assembly|Design for Assembly]], which means the design of the product for ease of assembly.
==Usage== DFMA is used as the basis for [[concurrent engineering]] studies to provide guidance to the design team in simplifying the product structure, to reduce manufacturing and assembly costs, and to quantify improvements. The practice of applying DFMA is to identify, quantify and eliminate waste or inefficiency in a product design. DFMA is therefore a component of [[Lean Manufacturing]] DFMA is also used as a benchmarking tool to study competitors’ products, and as a should cost tool to assist in supplier negotiations.<ref> Boothroyd, G., Dewhurst, P. and Knight, W., “Product Design for Manufacture and Assembly, 2nd Edition”, Marcel Dekker, New York, 2002.</ref>
==Software== DFMA is the name of the integrated set of software products from Boothroyd Dewhurst, Inc. that are used by companies to implement the DFMA methodology. DFMA is a registered trademark of Boothroyd Dewhurst, Inc.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * [http://www.designnews.com/article/510393-DFMA_Takes_a_Back_to_Basics_Product_Simplification_Strategy_to_Cut_Costs.php “DFMA Takes a Back-to-Basics Product Simplification Strategy to Cut Costs” September 2010 article from Design News magazine] * [http://www.nxtbook.com/nxtbooks/level5/desktopengineering_201007/index.php?bm=normal#/60 “DFMA Hits the Jackpot” July 2010 article from Desktop Engineering magazine] * [http://www.design-iv.com Official European DFMA Site] * [http://www.dfma.com DFMA Official Site]

{{coord|56.8962|-2.4512|type:edu|display=title}} {{Infobox artifact | name = The Fordoun Stone | image = Pictish.stone.Fordoun.jpg | image2 = | image_caption = The Fordoun Stone | material = [[Old Red Sandstone]] | size = {{convert|1.07|m|ft}} | writing = [[Ogham]] script:
VUN-MSETTORBBRE
Roman script:
Pidarnoin | created = | discovered = 18th Century CE | location = [[Auchenblae]], [[Aberdeenshire]] | classification = Class II cross slab | symbols = {{Plainlist| * Celtic cross * Hunting scene * Double disc and z-rod }} | civilization = [[Picts|Picto-Scottish]] }} The '''Fordoun Stone''' is a class II [[Pictish stones|Pictish cross slab]] in [[Fordoun]] parish church, [[Auchenblae]], [[Aberdeenshire]], [[Scotland]]. ==Description== A slab of [[Old Red Sandstone]], the cross slab was discovered in the late 18th century, having been reused as paving in [[Fordoun]] Parish Church.{{citation | title = The Pictish Symbol Stones of Scotland | publisher = Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historic Monuments of Scotland | last = Fraser | first = Iain | pages = 62–63 | location = Edinburgh | year = 2008}} The slab, now standing in the church bears a celtic cross with interlaced knotwork, a hunting scene and a [[Double disc (Pictish symbol)|double disc and z-rod]] design. It also bears inscriptions, [[Ogham]] script along the edges of the stone, '''VUN-MSETTORBBRE''' as well as an inscription in roman script, '''Pidarnoin''', on the face of the slab. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://canmore.rcahms.gov.uk/en/site/36458/details/auchenblae+fordoun+parish+church+fordoun+stone/ Entry in RCAHMS Canmore database] {{Pictish stones}} [[Category:Pictish stones]] [[Category:Pictish stones in Aberdeenshire]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company| |name = G. Peignot et Fils |logo = Logo-g-peignot-et-fils.png |type = [[Kommanditgesellschaft]] |genre = |foundation = 1898 |founder = Pierre Leclerc, Gustave Peignot |defunct = 1919 |location = [[Paris]], [[France]] |key_people = Georges Peignot |industry = [[Type foundry]] |num_employees = |revenue = |homepage = }} '''G. Peignot et Fils foundry''' (Fonderie G. Peignot et Fils) was a French [[type foundry|typographic foundry]], established in 1898 and closed down between 1919 and 1923 after a merger to become [[Deberny & Peignot|Deberny & Peignot foundry]]. Led by [[Georges Peignot]] (1872–1915), G. Peignot & Fils was a prestigious French typographic foundry, an "elite house",<ref>{{cite journal | authorlink = Louis Barthou | title = Lettres à un jeune français. XXV. La contagion sublime | journal = Les Annales | volume = | issue = 1727 | pages = | date = July 1916 | language = french}}</ref> according to [[Louis Barthou]], former French Prime Minister.
== History == G. Peignot et Fils is founded in 1898 in [[Paris]], after absorption of the '''Veuve Routier et Peignot''' foundry (established in 1867), itself heir of the foundry "Veuve Routier" (established in 1865) and foundry of Pierre Leclerc (established in 1842).
=== Foundry of Pierre Leclerc (1842) === In 1842, Pierre Leclerc, a craftsman, creates a [[Letter-spacing|fixed spaces]] foundry (hand-set metal type to achieve letter-spacing) in Paris. ''"He can be considered as the genuine creator of the fixed spaces industry"'', says the magazine ''La fonderie typographique'' in 1899.<ref>{{cite journal | authorlink = | title = Gustave Peignot | journal = La fonderie typographique | volume = | issue = 7 | pages = | date = 1899 | language = french}}</ref> These fixed spaces between words and lines, margins, etc., require great precision. He invents a new process, instead of cutting fixed spaces, pouring them into molds, which increases accuracy. In 1856, after his death,<ref name="Tuleu">{{Citation | last1 = Tuleu | first1 = Jane | title = Souvenirs de famille | place = Paris | publisher = Deberny |pages = 77 | date = 1915 | isbn = | language = french}}</ref> the company management is entrusted to a friend of his widow, Clémentine Dupont de Vieux Pont (wife Peignot, 1815-1897). She then settles beside her his son, Gustave Peignot (1839-1899), engineer of [[Arts et Métiers ParisTech|Arts et Métiers school]].<ref name="froissart">{{Citation | last1 = Froissart | first1 = Jean-Luc | title = L’or, l’âme et les cendres du plomb. L'épopée des Peignot, 1815-1983 | place = Paris | publisher = librairie Tekhnê |pages = | date = 2004 | isbn = 2-9522836-0-5 | language = french}}</ref>
=== Veuve Routier (1865) and Veuve Routier et G. Peignot (1867) foundries=== In 1865, the foundry of Pierre Leclerc is sold by auction to Peignot. The new company is called "Veuve Routier" (''Widow Routier''), which is the name of the lessor having made possible the purchase by Gustave Peignot. In 1867, Gustave Peignot and the lessor merge in a company which takes the name of "Veuve Routier et Peignot."
In 1869 the company moved to Boulevard de Montrouge (now boulevard Edgar-Quinet), at no. 66-68, where a building is constructed (upstairs for the family, ground for the plant).<ref name="Tuleu" /> In 1875, the debt to the Veuve Routier is cleared, and Gustave Peignot becomes sole owner of the company and the building. [[File:1883-g-peignot-fonderie-publicite.png|thumb|600 px|Advertisement for G. Peignot foundry published in ''L'imprimerie'' magazine, in 1883]]
From 1875 to 1898, Gustave Peignot continues to make great profits with fixed spaces production, not amputated this time by refunds to the Veuve Routier. ''"In this lead will Thou find gold"'', used to say his mother.<ref name="froissart" /> At this time, Gustave Peignot becomes first President of the Chambre syndicale des maîtres fondeurs typographes (trade association of type foundry masters). He marries Marie Laporte, and is a father of 8 children.
=== G. Peignot et Fils Foundry (1898)=== In 1898, Gustave Peignot distributes to his children an equal parts of stocks and appoints Georges Peignot, his second son, as co-manager.<ref name="Tuleu" /> The company's name changes for "G. Peignot & Fils" (''G. Peignot & Sons''). He dies in 1899.
Georges Peignot continues the production of fixed spaces, causing significant growth in sales, and launches studies for new [[typeface]]s. The quality of fonts puts foundry G. Peignot et Fils at the forefront. In 12 years, Georges Peignot creates many typefaces: [[Grasset (typeface)|Grasset]], [[Auriol (typeface)|Auriol]], [[Cochin (typeface)|Cochin]], [[Garamond (typeface)|Garamond-Peignot]], [[Bellery-Desfontaines (typeface)|Bellery-Desfontaines]], [[Naudin (typeface)|Naudin]], [[Guy-Arnoux (typeface)|Guy-Arnoux]]. He also publishes a ''Specimen'', great typefaces catalog (still highly sought, 600 pages, 2 volumes).
In 1904, to address growth of sales, G. Peignot et Fils built a new plant at the corner of [[Rue Cabanis (Paris)|Cabanis]] and [[Rue Ferrus (Paris)|Ferrus]] streets. In 1911-1912, Georges Peignot sends in South America his two young brothers, Lucien and Rémy, looking for distributors. The company is at its peak.
But war brakes out in 1914. Volunteer for the front, Adjudant Georges Peignot is killed by a bullet to the forehead at the head of his section, Sept. 28, 1915, near Givenchy.<ref name="froissart">{{Citation | last1 = Froissart | first1 = Jean-Luc | title = L’or, l’âme et les cendres du plomb. L'épopée des Peignot, 1815-1983 | place = Paris | publisher = librairie Tekhnê |pages = | date = 2004 | isbn = 2-9522836-0-5 | language = french}}</ref> His four brothers also die.
The legacy of Georges Peignot is taken hostage by infighting: in 1919, his own mother, Marie Laporte-Peignot, requires its children or their widows the payment of a substantial sum (1 million of French francs, equivalent of USD [2015] 1,4 million) in the form of a capital increase<ref name="froissart" /> to its competitor Deberny (founded by [[Honoré de Balzac|Balzac]] in 1826), owned by Charles Tuleu (heir of Alexandre de Berny and husband of Jane Peignot-Tuleu). In 1923, G. Peignot et Fils foundry disappears, victim of the merger between Deberny foundry (2.6 million, including the 1 million Peignot subsidy) and G. Peignot & Fils foundry (4.1 million). The new company's name relegates Peignot's name in background: the new entity is indeed called "[[Deberny et Peignot]]" and commonly called "Deberny". Against all logic (the manager is usually chosen by the majority shareholder), the manager of the small Deberny foundry, Robert Girard, under whom the old foundry Deberny had collapsed,<ref name="froissart" /> takes the reins of the new entity.
In 1922, the Commission de l’enseignement et des beaux-arts (governmental ''Commission for education and fine arts'') suggests honoring the story of Peignot: it transports the awls of the foundry in the building of the Imprimerie nationale (Government printing office), near [[Rue Gutenberg (Paris)|Gutenberg street]] in [[Paris]]. And it proposes that the continuation of this street would be baptized "[[Rue des Quatre-Frères-Peignot (Paris)|rue des Quatre-Frères-Peignot]]" (''Four-brothers-Peignot street'') in memory of Georges, André, Lucien and Rémy who died between September, 1914 and June, 1916, snatched by the World War I.
== Typographical creations == G. Peignot & Fils foundry is the heart of important typographic creations, including: * the [[Grasset (typeface)|Grasset]] (drawing with reed pen : [[Eugène Grasset]], 1898-1901) ; * the [[Auriol (typeface)|Française-légère]], the [[Auriol (typeface)|Française-allongée]], the [[Auriol (typeface)|Auriol-labeur]], the [[Auriol (typeface)|Auriol-champlevé]], and the [[Auriol (typeface)|Robur]] (drawing with brush : [[George Auriol]], 1902-1907) ; * the [[Bellery-Desfontaines (typeface)|Bellery-Desfontaines-large]] et le [[Bellery-Desfontaines (typeface)|Bellery-Desfontaines-étroit]] (drawing : [[Henri Bellery-Desfontaines]], 1910-1912) ; * the [[Polyphème (typeface)|Polyphème]] (bold) et le [[Cyclopéen (typeface)|Cyclopéen]] (light) (anonymous creation, 1910) ; * the [[Cochin (typeface)|Cochin]] book and italic, the [[Nicolas-Cochin (typeface)|Nicolas-Cochin]] book and italic, engraved by [[Charles Malin]], the [[Moreau-le-Jeune (typeface)|Moreau-le-Jeune]], the [[Fournier-le-Jeune (typeface)|Fournier-le-Jeune]], the vignettes et ornaments [[Fournier (typeface)|Fournier]] (drawing : P. Roy et A. Marty) ; * the [[Garamond (typeface)|Garamond]] book and italic (engraved by Henri Parmentier, from prints on rag paper of the genuine Garamond typeface, under careful control of [[Georges Peignot]] (1912-1914) ; launched in 1926) ; * the [[Naudin (typeface)|Naudin]] book, italic and champlevé (drawing : [[Bernard Naudin]], 1909-1914 ; launched in 1924) ; * the [[Guy-Arnoux (typeface)|Guy-Arnoux capitales]] (drawing : [[Guy Arnoux]], 1914).
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== * {{Citation | last1 = Froissart | first1 = Jean-Luc | title = L’or, l’âme et les cendres du plomb. L'épopée des Peignot, 1815-1983 | place = Paris | publisher = librairie Tekhnê |pages = | date = 2004 | isbn = 2-9522836-0-5 | language = french}} * Amelia Hugill-Fontanel, 2002. [http://amgweb.rit.edu/dphist2.htm II: History of the Peignot Typefoundry]. Website part of a Graphic Arts Publishing Master thesis of Rochester Institute of Technology (USA) * Linotype, 2007 [http://www.linotype.com/546/georgespeignot.html Georges Peignot] * [[Michel Wlassikoff]], 2014. [http://signes.org/set.php?id=275 Les Cochins, spécimen de la fonderie Deberny et Peignot (1932)]. Signes, website

{{EngvarB|date=February 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox company |logo=Grimshaw Company logo.svg |logo_size=200px |name=Grimshaw Architects |industry=Architecture |foundation=London, United Kingdom

London
New York City
[[Melbourne]]
Sydney |area_served=Worldwide |key_people=[[Sir Nicholas Grimshaw]]
(chairman)
[[Andrew Whalley]]
([[Deputy chairman]]) |services=Architecture, [[Industrial Design]] |website=[http://www.grimshaw-architects.com Grimshaw] }} '''Grimshaw Architects''' (formerly '''Nicholas Grimshaw & Partners''') is an [[architectural firm]] based in London. Founded in 1980 by Sir [[Nicholas Grimshaw]], the firm was one of the pioneers of [[high-tech architecture]].{{cite web |url=http://www.crowstep.co.uk/Resources/HighTechArchitecture.pdf |title=High Tech Architecture |author=Davies, Colin |accessdate=2 April 2009}} In particular, they are known for their design of transport projects including [[Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station]], [[Waterloo International railway station]] and the award-winning [[Southern Cross railway station]] recipient of the [[Royal Institute of British Architects]] Lubetkin Prize.{{cite web |url=http://www.worldarchitecturenews.com/index.php?fuseaction=wanappln.projectview&upload_id=1169 |title=Grimshaw's Southern Cross Station wins Lubetkin prize |author=World Architecture News |accessdate=26 October 2011}} The firm currently has offices in London, [[Melbourne]], Sydney, and New York City. ==Organisation== ===Partners=== Grimshaw has 17 partners worldwide: Jolyon Brewis, Keith Brewis, Vincent Chang, Andrew Cortese, [[Sir Nicholas Grimshaw]], William Horgan, Mark Husser, Ewan Jones, [[Kirsten Lees]], Declan McCafferty, Neill McClements, Mark Middleton, Juan Porral, Neven Sidor, Neil Stonell, Andrew Thomas, Andrew Whalley.{{cite web |url=http://architypesource.com/architects/629-grimshaw-architects |title=Grimshaw Architects Profile |author=ArchitypeSource |accessdate=26 October 2011}} ==Project list== Major projects, by year of completion and ordered by type, are: [[Image:Eden Project geodesic domes panorama.jpg|thumb|360px|Panoramic view of the geodesic biome domes at the Eden Project]] ===Arts and culture=== [[File:Thermae Bath Spa.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Thermae Bath Spa: the main building, 2006]] *British Pavilion, Expo '92, [[Seville]], Spain, 1992 *Caixia Galicia Art Foundation, [[A Coruña]], Spain, 2006 *[[Eden Project]], Cornwall, UK, 2001 *[[Experimental Media and Performing Arts Center]] (EMPAC), [[Troy, New York|Troy]], US, 2008 *Horno 3: Museo del Acero, [[Museum of Steel]], [[Monterrey]], Mexico, 2007 *Mobilizarte Mobile Pavilion, [[Brazil]], 2012 *[[National Space Centre]], [[Leicester]], UK, 2001 *[[Oxford Ice Rink]], [[Oxford]], UK, 1984 *Patricia and Phillip Frost Museum of Science, Miami, US 2014 *[[Queens Museum of Art]], [[Queens]], 2013 *[[Thermae Bath Spa]], [[Bath, Somerset|Bath]], 2006 ===Bridges=== [[File:National Space Centre, Leicester.jpg|thumb|right|The National Space Centre in [[Leicester]]]] *[[IJburg Bridge]], Amsterdam, The Netherlands, 2001 *A40 Western Avenue Footbridge, London, UK, 2009 ===Science and education=== *[[Eden Project]]: The Core, [[Cornwall]], UK, 2005 *[[New York University]] Polytechnic: Rogers Hall, [[Brooklyn]], US, 2011 *[[London South Bank University]], London, UK, 2010 *[[London School of Economics]]: New Academic Building, London, UK, 2009 *[[University College London]]: Roberts Building Front Extension, London, UK, 2007 *[[University College London]] Cancer Institute: Paul O Gorman Building, London, UK, 2007 ===Transport=== [[File:Southern-cross-station-main-concourse.jpg|thumb|The main concourse of Southern Cross Station]] [[File:Pulkovo_International_Airport.jpg|thumb|Entrance to [[Pulkovo Airport|Pulkovo]]'s new terminal.]] *[[Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station|Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA Station]], Amsterdam, Netherlands, 2007 *[[Fulton Center]], [[Manhattan]], US, 2014 *[[Heathrow Airport]] Terminal 1, Pier 4A, UK, 1993 *[[Heathrow Airport]] Terminal 2B, UK, 2009 *[[Waterloo International railway station|International Terminal, Waterloo Sation]], London, UK, 1993 *[[Istanbul New Airport]] (under construction) *[[Manchester Airport]] Terminal 3, UK, 1998 *[[Paddington Station]], London, UK, 1999 *[[Pulkovo Airport]], St. Petersburg, Russia, 2013 *[[Southern Cross railway station]], [[Melbourne]], Australia, 2006 *[[Vaughan Metropolitan Centre (TTC)]] station, Vaughan, Canada (under construction and planned completion 2018) *[[Zurich Airport]], Zurich, Switzerland, 2004 ===Office=== [[File:Nicholas Grimshaw flats Camden Town back of Sainsburys.jpg|thumb|300px|Grand Union Walk Housing – Flats behind Sainsbury's supermarket, Camden Town, 1988]] *25 Gresham Street, London, UK, 2002 *385 Bourke Street, [[Melbourne]], Australia, 2008 *British Airways Operations, London, UK, 1993 *[[Eden Project]]: The Foundation, [[Cornwall]], UK, 2002 *Five Boats Houding, [[Duisburg]], Germany, 2005 *Ludwig Erhaud Haus, [[Berlin]], Germany, 1998 *Orange Operational Centre and Customer Service Facilities, [[Darlington]], UK, 1998 *RAC Regional Control Centre, [[Bristol]], UK, 1994 *The [[St Botolphs Building]], London, UK, 2010 ===Industry=== *Donald Danforth Plant Center, [[St. Louis]], US, 2001 *Financial Times Printworks, London, UK, 1988 *Herman Miller Factory, [[Chippenham]], UK, 1976 *Igus Factory & Headquarters, [[Cologne]], Germany, 2000 *Rolls-Royce Manufacturing Plant & Headquarters, [[West Sussex]], UK, 2003 *Vitra Furniture Factory, [[Weil am Rhein]], Germany, 1981 *Western Morning News, [[Plymouth]],UK, 1993 ===Mixed use=== *Sainsbury's Store & Grand Union Walk Housing, London, UK, 1988 *Via Verde – The Green Way, [[The Bronx]], US, 2012 == Awards == ===2015=== * [http://aianycoteawards.org/winners/ AIA New York COTE Award – Via Verde (designed with Dattner Architects)] ===2012=== *Carbuncle Cup – Building Design Awards ===2009=== *AIA Honor Award – Horno 3: Museo Del Acero ===2008=== *Architectural Practice of the Year – Building Design Awards *World Architect of the Year – Building Design Awards *Transport Architect of the Year – Building Design Awards *[[RIBA European Award#2008|2008 RIBA European Award]] – [[Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station|Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA Station]] *Royal Institute of Dutch Architects – [[Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station|Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA Station]] *[[Stirling Prize]] Runner up – [[Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA railway station|Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA Station]] ===2007=== *Lubetkin Prize – Southern Cross Station, Melbourne, Australia *2007 RIBA International Award – Southern Cross Station, Melbourne, Australia{{cite web |url=http://www.architecture.com/Awards/RIBAInternationalAwards/2007/Home.aspx |title=RIBA International Awards / Winners 2007 |author=RIBA website |accessdate=8 December 2011}} == Exhibitions == Grimshaw's first exhibition titled ''Product + Process'' debuted in 1988. The firm has since produced four exhibitions: ''Structure Space + Skin'' (1993), ''Fusion'' {{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KK78bZMFFYcC&pg=PA246&lpg=PA246&dq=fusion+grimshaw+architects+exhibition&source=bl&ots=VxreBYX4NR&sig=ThiHe2ZmGqve_JNTYSTyQsW_gNQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zZoeUfzXOs-y0QH9loHwCQ&ved=0CFUQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=fusion%20grimshaw%20architects%20exhibition&f=false|title=International Architecture Yearbook 7|author=Images Publishing|accessdate=15 February 2013}} (1998), ''Equilibrium''{{cite web |url=http://www.hughpearman.com/book2/index.html|title=Equilibrium: The Work of Nicholas Grimshaw and Partners|author=Hugh Pearman|accessdate=15 February 2013}} (2000), and ''Micro to Macro: Grimshaw in New York'' {{cite web |url=http://www.aiany.org/eOCULUS/newsletter/?p=183|title=Macro to Micro: Grimshaw in New York|author=E-Oculus|accessdate=15 February 2013}} (2007). The latest exhibition, ''Equation'': Design Inspired by Nature, launched on Wednesday, 20 February 2013 at The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) Centre in Singapore. ''Equation'' explores a series of themes that investigate biomimicry, biophilia and ecosystems and their influence on design.{{cite web |url=http://www.ura.gov.sg/aude/grimshaw/|title=Equation|author=URA|accessdate=15 February 2013}} ==Publications== *Grimshaw Architecture: The First Thirty Years{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Grimshaw-Architecture-First-30-Years/dp/3791350730|title=Grimshaw Architects: The First 30 Year|publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} *Blue 02: Systems and Structure{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Blue-Issue-2-Systems-Structure/dp/0982587511/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1323362579&sr=1-1|title=Blue 02: Systems and Structure |publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} *Blue 01: Water, Energy and Waste{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Blue-Issue-Water-Energy-Waste/dp/0982587503/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&s=books&qid=1309425095&sr=8-5|title=Blue 01: Water, Energy and Waste|publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} *The Sketchbooks of [[Nicholas Grimshaw]]{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Sketchbooks-Nicholas-Grimshaw-Peter-Davey/dp/190571162X/ref=sr_1_9?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1323361382&sr=1-9|title=The Sketchbooks of Nicholas Grimshaw|publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} *The Making of Station Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA{{cite web |url=http://www.sdu.nl/catalogus/9789012129305|title=The Making of Station Amsterdam Bijlmer ArenA|author=Sdu Uitgevers|accessdate=8 December 2012}} *The Architecture of Eden{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Architecture-Eden-Hugh-Pearman/dp/1903919150/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1323362185&sr=1-1|title=The Architecture of Eden|publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} *Equilibrium{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Equilibrium-Nicholas-Grimshaw-Partners-Pearman/dp/0714839582/ref=sr_1_16?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1323361738&sr=1-16|title=Equilibrium|publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} *Grimshaw: Architecture, Industry and Innovation{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Grimshaw-Architecture-Industry-Innovation-Nicholas/dp/0714839345/ref=sr_1_20?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1323361777&sr=1-20|title=Grimshaw: Architecture, Industry and Innovation|publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} *Structure, Space and Skin: The Work of Nicholas Grimshaw & Partners{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/Structure-Space-Skin-Nicholas-Grimshaw/dp/0714834572/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1323361265&sr=1-3|title=Structure, Space and Skin: The Work of Nicholas Grimshaw & Partners|publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} *British Pavilion Seville Exposition{{cite web |url=https://www.amazon.com/British-Pavilion-Saville-Architecture-Detail/dp/0714827479/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1323361965&sr=1-1|title=British Pavilion Seville Exposition|publisher=Amazon.com |accessdate=8 December 2012}} == See also == *[[:Category:Nicholas Grimshaw buildings|Nicholas Grimshaw buildings and structures]] *[[List of architecture firms]] *[[List of architects]] == References
